verses.sanskrit: दृष्ट्वे॒मं स्वजनं कृष्ण युयुत्सुं समुपस्थि॒तम् । सीदन्ति मम गात्राणि मुखं च परिवुष्यति ॥
verses.transliteration: dṛṣṭvēmam svajanaṁ kṛṣṇa yuyutsum samupasthitam | sīdanti mama gātrāṇi mukhaṁ ca pariśuṣyati ||
verses.translation: Having-seen this my-own-people, O Krishna, desirous-to-fight, having-come-near; (then) weaken my limbs and (my) mouth also becomes dry.
verses.context: This verse occurs at the opening of Arjuna's lament on the battlefield (Kurukṣetra), when he beholds relatives, teachers, and friends arrayed on both sides. Philosophically it marks the transition from external duty (kṣetra) to an inward crisis of values and identity. Arjuna's perception shifts from warrior role to a person confronting intimate relationships and the moral cost of action; the verse sets up the need for deeper counsel about dharma, selfhood, and the distinction between social role and spiritual discernment.
verses.explanation: Arjuna’s breakdown is not weakness; it is the human cost of ethical conflict. When duty clashes with attachment, the body reacts before the mind can reason.
verses.detailed_explanation: Arjuna’s physiological symptoms—weak limbs, dry mouth—are early markers of acute moral stress. Psychologically, the body enacts the mind’s collapse when identity roles conflict: son, friend, warrior. Modern application: in professions where duty may harm loved ones (soldiers, first responders, doctors), acknowledging bodily signals can prevent rash choices. Mindful pause, supervision, and ethical dialogue convert overwhelm into considered action. The verse invites integrating somatic awareness with moral reasoning to avoid decisions driven solely by obligation or fear.

verses.sanskrit: न च श्रेयोऽनुपश्यामि हत्वा स्वजनम् अहवे ।
verses.transliteration: na ca śreyo 'nupaśyāmi hatvā sva-janam ahave |
verses.translation: And not (do) I (see) the better/benefit; after killing (my) own-people in the battle (ahave).
verses.context: This line is part of Arjuna’s spoken declaration prior to laying down his bow. Standing on the chariot, he evaluates the moral outcome of victory gained through slaughter of kin. The philosophical issue is the conflict between svadharma (one's duty as a warrior) and broader dharma that values life and familial bonds. Arjuna’s doubt exposes the Gītā’s central concern: how should one act when prescribed duty appears to violate higher ethical principles? It prompts Krishna’s teaching on action, duty, and vision of the Self.
verses.explanation: Arjuna recognizes that success can still feel like failure when it violates core values. This verse speaks to situations where winning does not bring peace.
verses.detailed_explanation: Arjuna’s refusal reveals a moral calculus: tactical success vs. ethical cost. Psychologically, this is cognitive dissonance—acting for duty while conscience protests. In modern contexts (whistleblowing, military orders, corporate choices), individuals must weigh institutional directives against personal ethics. The verse encourages pausing to reassess values before acting, seeking counsel, and recognizing that adherence to role-based duty without moral reflection can produce long-term psychological harm. It models moral courage to question the presumed ‘right’ action.

verses.sanskrit: कुलक्षये प्रणश्यन्ति कुलधर्माः सनातनाः । धर्मसंहिनास्ते कुप्यन्ति कुलविशोऽभविष्यति ॥
verses.transliteration: kulakṣaye praṇaśyanti kula-dharmāḥ sanātanāḥ | dharma-saṁhinās te kupyanti kula-viṣo 'bhaviṣyati ||
verses.translation: When the family-line is destroyed, the ancient family-duties are ruined; those lacking adherence to dharma become angry and family-poison will arise.
verses.context: Arjuna here shifts from personal distress to concern for societal continuity: the erosion of kula-dharma (family/lineage duties) and its long-term consequences. In the epic framework, the collapse of family order leads to social disorder, cyclical degeneration, and loss of inherited moral structures. Philosophically, this verse articulates the interdependence between personal action and communal norms, raising questions about duties to family versus duties to righteousness, and whether preserving social order can justify violent means.
verses.explanation: Arjuna’s concern extends beyond himself. He recognizes that harm ripples outward, affecting structures larger than individuals.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse highlights systemic trauma: one violent act can destabilize family roles and moral education across generations. Psychologically, it anticipates transgenerational transmission of harm—children inherit disrupted norms and reactive patterns. Modern application: policymakers and leaders should consider long-term social costs of violence and policy choices (war, punitive justice). For therapists and families, it underscores repairing relational ruptures and fostering resilient moral frameworks to prevent the perpetuation of destructive behaviors.

verses.sanskrit: एवमुक्त्वा अर्जुनः सङ्ख्ये रथोपस्थः उपविशत ।
verses.transliteration: evam uktvā arjunaḥ saṅkhye rathopastha upaviśat |
verses.translation: Having thus spoken, Arjuna on the battlefield (saṅkhye), sitting upon the chariot-bench sat down.
verses.context: This verse concludes Arjuna’s opening collapse: after voicing his doubts and reluctance, he places his bow aside and sits. Narratively it creates the pause that invites Krishna’s teaching. Philosophically it signifies the cessation of the warrior’s automatic performance of role and the commencement of an inquiry into action’s meaning. The scene sets the Gītā’s pedagogical frame: a teacher (Krishna) addressing a student (Arjuna) at a moment of existential paralysis.
verses.explanation: Sometimes collapse precedes clarity. This pause creates space for deeper understanding rather than impulsive action.
verses.detailed_explanation: Arjuna’s sitting down is a deliberate bodily signal of psychological shutdown and openness. It models a constructive pause rather than avoidance: stepping back from automatic duties to allow reflection. In modern life, intentional disengagement from role-driven activity—sabbaticals, supervision, therapy—can prevent ethical errors and burnout. Psychologically, this pause enables perspective-taking, clarity, and receptivity to guidance. The verse supports creating structured pauses in high-stakes contexts to re-evaluate motives and consequences before acting.

verses.sanskrit: कार्पण्यदोषोपहतस्वभावः पृच्छामि त्वां धर्मसम्मूढचेताः । यच्छ्रेयः स्यान्निश्चितं ब्रूहि तन्मे शिष्यस्तेऽहं शाधि मां त्वां प्रपन्नम् ॥
verses.transliteration: Kārpaṇya-doṣopahata-svabhāvaḥ pṛcchāmi tvāṁ dharma-sammūḍha-cetāḥ । yac chreyaḥ syān niścitaṁ brūhi tan me śiṣyas te 'haṁ śādhi māṁ tvāṁ prapannam ॥
verses.translation: kārpaṇya‑doṣa‑upahata‑svabhāvaḥ — nature struck/overcome by the fault (of) pity/compassion; pṛcchāmi tvāṁ — I ask you; dharma‑sammūḍha‑cetāḥ — (being) mind/deluded regarding dharma; yac chreyaḥ syāt niścitaṁ — what (is) certainly better; brūhi tan me — speak that to me; śiṣyas te aham — I (am) your disciple; śādhi māṁ tvāṁ prapannam — make (me) steady, (I) having surrendered unto you.
verses.context: Setting: On the battlefield of Kurukṣetra, Arjuna, his chariot halted and his heart shaken, addresses Krishna. Psychologically overwhelmed by the prospect of fighting relatives and teachers, Arjuna confesses that his nature is clouded by pity and moral bewilderment. Philosophically this verse opens the central didactic exchange: a disciple's honest admission of confusion and surrender to the teacher. It frames the Bhagavad‑Gītā as a teaching not for the certain but for the perplexed, initiating Krishna's systematic exposition on duty, self, action, and liberation.
verses.explanation: This verse establishes that clarity begins with honesty. The Gita does not shame doubt; it treats it as a valid human state. Arjuna’s strength here is not certainty, but the willingness to admit he does not know. In modern life, confusion often appears when values clash. This verse reassures that asking for help is not weakness but readiness for growth.
verses.detailed_explanation: Arjuna’s candid surrender models a mature psychological stance: acknowledging cognitive and emotional overwhelm opens the path to transformation. Rather than acting from denial or rigid certainty, he seeks guidance, which allows for integration of values, duties, and feelings. In contemporary terms, this is the therapeutic posture—owning uncertainty and consulting a trusted mentor or inner wisdom. Practically, it teaches pausing to name confusion, refraining from reactive choices, and inviting disciplined inquiry so decisions align with deeper principles rather than transient fear or compassion.

verses.sanskrit: देहिनोऽस्मिन् यथा देहे कौमारं यौवनं जरा तथा देहिनोऽस्मिन् अन्यदेहानि प्राप्नुवन्ति ॥
verses.transliteration: Dehino 'smin yathā dehe kaumāraṁ yauvanaṁ jarā tathā dehino 'smin anyadehāni prāpnu-vanti ॥
verses.translation: dehino 'smin — in the embodied (one) in this; yathā — just as; dehe — in the body; kaumāram — childhood; yauvanam — youth; jarā — old age; tathā — so/in the same manner; dehino 'smin — in the embodied (one); anyadehāni — other bodies; prāpnuvanti — they obtain/enter (are obtained).
verses.context: Narrative and philosophical setting: Krishna addresses Arjuna’s grief about death and loss by reframing identity. Within the discourse on the self (ātman) versus the body (deha), this verse introduces the doctrine of the enduring self that experiences sequential bodily states. It contrasts transient bodily phases with the continuity of the embodied principle, preparing Arjuna to see death and change as transitions rather than annihilation. This sets up later verses on immortality and karmic continuity that undergird Krishna’s ethical counsel to perform duty without attachment.
verses.explanation: Krishna does not deny grief but places it within a wider frame. Change is constant, even when painful. This verse helps loosen the belief that loss is annihilation. Understanding impermanence does not erase pain, but it softens resistance to it.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically this verse invites a shift from identification with a single, fragile identity to seeing oneself as a process that persists through changing forms. Modern application: when faced with loss, role changes, or aging, one can cultivate continuity of values, memory, and purpose rather than collapse into despair. Therapeutically, it supports narrative re‑framing—viewing life as chapters rather than a single catastrophic event—reducing existential anxiety and enabling adaptive transitions through role change and bereavement.

verses.sanskrit: मात्रास्पर्शास्तु कौन्तेय शीतोष्णसुखदुःखदाः । आगमापायिनोऽनित्यास्तांस्तितिक्षस्व भारत ॥
verses.transliteration: Mātrā-sparśās tu kaunteya śītoṣṇa-sukha‑duḥkha‑dāḥ | āgam‑āpāyino 'nityās tāṁs titikṣasva bhārata ||
verses.translation: mātrā‑sparśāḥ tu — the contacts (with sense‑objects) are but small/measurements; kaunteya — O son of Kunti; śīta‑uṣṇa‑sukha‑duḥkha‑dāḥ — (they are) givens of cold and heat, pleasure and pain; āgama‑āpāyinaḥ — coming and going/temporary; anityāḥ — impermanent; tān — those; titikṣasva — endure/put up with; bhārata — O descendant of Bharata.
verses.context: Krishna, responding to Arjuna’s emotional turbulence, explains the transient nature of sensory impressions. In the battlefield context this instructs Arjuna to withstand ephemeral comforts and discomforts that sway action. Philosophically it anchors non‑attachment: because pleasures and pains are transient, one should cultivate forbearance. This counsel prepares Arjuna to act from steadiness rather than momentary inclination, framing an ethic of disciplined endurance amid fluctuating situational pressures.
verses.explanation: This verse encourages endurance without denial. Experiences feel intense, but they do not define us permanently. Strength lies in recognizing their temporary nature rather than reacting impulsively.
verses.detailed_explanation: The verse trains psychological tolerance: sensing that sensations rise and fall weakens impulsive reactivity. In contemporary terms, it parallels mindfulness—observing pleasant and painful feelings as transient events rather than commanding facts. Practically, this supports stress resilience: pause, note impermanence, and choose responses aligned with long‑term goals. For professionals and caregivers, it reduces burnout by reframing episodic discomfort as passing, enabling sustained engagement without being hijacked by momentary highs or lows.

verses.sanskrit: यं हि न व्यथयन्त्येते पुरुषं पुरुषर्षभ । समदुःखसुखं धारयतो धीरः स्याद् ॥
verses.transliteration: Yaṁ hi na vyathayanty ete puruṣaṁ puruṣarṣabha । sama‑duḥkha‑sukhaṁ dhārayato dhīraḥ syād ॥
verses.translation: yaṁ hi — that which indeed; na — not; vyathayanti — disturb/perturb; ete — these; puruṣam — a person/man; puruṣarṣabha — O best of men (address to Arjuna); sama‑duḥkha‑sukhaṁ — equal (in) pain and pleasure; dhārayataḥ — by holding/maintaining; dhīraḥ syāt — one becomes steady/courageous.
verses.context: Following the claim that sensations are transient, Krishna describes the ideal psychological stance. Addressing Arjuna as puruṣarṣabha (foremost of men), he says: the person whom these (pleasures and pains) do not disturb, who sustains equal-mindedness, becomes steadfast. In the dialogue this is a pivotal normative claim: equanimity is the mark of the spiritually mature agent, essential for right action (dharma) free from attachment and aversion.
verses.explanation: Resilience is not numbness but balance. Stability grows from reduced reactivity.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse pinpoints equanimity as a core psychological skill: the ability not to be tossed by pleasure or pain. Modern application includes emotion regulation, cognitive reappraisal, and stress inoculation—techniques that cultivate steady performance under pressure. For leaders and caregivers, it advises maintaining composure so decisions are not driven by transient states. Therapeutically, training in tolerance and perspective reduces impulsive avoidance or clinging, fostering sustained, value‑aligned action even in adversity.

verses.sanskrit: स्वधर्ममपि चावेक्ष्य न विकम्पितुमर्हसि । धर्म्याद्धि युद्धाच्छ्रेयोऽन्यत्क्षत्रियस्य न विद्यते ॥
verses.transliteration: svadharmam api ca avekṣya na vikampitum arhasi | dharmyād dhi yuddhāc chreyo 'nyat kṣatriyasya na vidyate ||
verses.translation: svadharmam — one’s own duty; api — even/also; ca — and; avekṣya — having considered/looked at; na — not; vikampitum — to be shaken/tremble; arhasi — you ought/you must; dharmyāt — from righteousness/duty; hi — certainly/indeed; yuddhāt — from battle/war; chreyaḥ — better; anyat — other/another; kṣatriyasya — of a Kshatriya (warrior); na — not; vidyate — exists/is found. (Literal sense:) Having considered even your own duty, you ought not to tremble; for from a righteous battle there is no better (course) for a Kshatriya.
verses.context: Scene: On the battlefield of Kurukṣetra, Arjuna is overwhelmed with moral confusion and refuses to fight his kin. Krishna, his charioteer and teacher, responds by reminding him of svadharma — the responsibilities tied to his social role as a Kṣatriya. Philosophically, Krishna locates duty within a broader dharmic order: action aligned with one’s ordained role, when righteous, is preferable to inaction. This verse begins Krishna’s argument that ethical identity and societal function can justify accepting difficult but proper action.
verses.explanation: Responsibility clarifies action when emotion clouds judgment.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically, this verse addresses role-induced anxiety: when identity and duty conflict with emotion, clarifying one’s responsibilities reduces paralysis. For modern readers, the teaching invites examination of professional and relational roles (parent, manager, caregiver) as sources of purpose that can override transient fears. It cautions against using discomfort as a reason to abandon obligations that sustain social and moral order. Applied therapeutically, it encourages values-based action—choosing actions consistent with deeper commitments rather than momentary avoidance.

verses.sanskrit: अथ चेत्त्वमिमं धर्म्यं संग्रामं न करिष्यसि । ततोऽपि ते न प्रतिष्ठा न भविष्यति यावत्परम् ॥
verses.transliteration: atha cet tvam imaṃ dharmyaṃ saṅgrāmaṃ na kariṣyasi | tato 'pi te na pratiṣṭhā na bhaviṣyati yāvat param ||
verses.translation: atha — but if; cet — indeed/if; tvam — you; imam — this; dharmyam — righteous/dharmic; saṅgrāmam — battle/war; na — not; kariṣyasi — you will do; tato — then/even then; api — even; te — your; na — not; pratiṣṭhā — reputation/fame/standing; na — not; bhaviṣyati — will be; yāvat param — to the utmost/forever. (Literal sense:) But if you will not engage in this righteous battle, then even your reputation will not endure to the full.
verses.context: After asserting the importance of svadharma, Krishna anticipates Arjuna’s refusal. Here he warns of social and personal consequences: shirking a rightful duty damages one’s standing and legacy. In the Kurukṣetra narrative, reputation and duty are not mere pride but integral to sustaining dharma across generations—leaders who fail their role disrupt social order. Philosophically, the verse links ethical action to social recognition and continuity: moral courage secures honor and the capacity to protect others.
verses.explanation: Avoidance does not remove responsibility; it only postpones its cost.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse examines how fear-driven withdrawal harms self-concept and relationships. Psychologically, failing to act from fear erodes credibility and self-efficacy, producing guilt and long-term identity damage. In modern life, repeatedly avoiding difficult but necessary tasks—confrontations, decisions, obligations—diminishes trust from others and one’s own confidence. The teaching encourages confronting discomfort to preserve integrity: accept short-term stress to maintain long-term character, reputation, and the capacity to fulfill responsibilities that sustain communal well‑being.

verses.sanskrit: सुखदुःखे समे कृत्वा लाभालाभौ जयाजयौ । ततो युद्ध्यस्व विगतज्वरः ॥
verses.transliteration: sukha-duḥkhe same kṛtvā lābhā-lābhau jayā-jayau | tato yuddhyasva vigata-jvaraḥ ||
verses.translation: sukha-duḥkhe — in pleasure and pain; same — equal; kṛtvā — having made/regarded; lābhā-lābhau — gain and non‑gain (profit and loss); jayā‑ajayau — victory and defeat; tataḥ — therefore/thence; yuddhyasva — fight/engage in battle; vigata‑jvaraḥ — free from fever/without agitation. (Literal sense:) Regard pleasure and pain, gain and loss, victory and defeat as equal; therefore fight, free from agitation.
verses.context: Krishna now instructs Arjuna in emotional equanimity as a foundation for right action. Amid the battlefield’s extremes, he prescribes indifference to dualities that typically derail judgment—pleasure versus pain, profit versus loss, success versus failure. In narrative terms, this steadiness enables a warrior to perform duty without attachment to outcomes. Philosophically, the verse reflects the Gītā’s core: detachment from fruit while engaging fully in right action (karma-yoga).
verses.detailed_explanation: This teaching targets affective reactivity: attachment to outcomes catalyzes anxiety and impulsive behavior. Psychologically, equanimity—treating wins and losses with measured perspective—reduces rumination and fear-driven avoidance. For contemporary application, it encourages process‑orientation over outcome fixation: focus on doing one’s role with integrity rather than being overwhelmed by success or failure. In leadership, therapy, and personal goals, cultivating non-reactive presence improves decision-making, resilience, and sustainable motivation, allowing consistent, ethical action under pressure.

verses.sanskrit: एषा तेऽभिहिता साङ्ख्ये बुद्धिर्ज्ञानयोगे त्विमां शृणु । उपदेक्ष्यामि बुद्धियोगं तया वृत्तोच्छेदचेत्सु ॥
verses.transliteration: eṣā te 'abhihitā sāṅkhye buddhir jñāna‑yoge tv imāṃ śṛṇu | upadekṣyāmi buddhi‑yogaṃ tayā vṛtto‑ccheda‑cetsu ||
verses.translation: eṣā — this (te = to you) has been declared; te — to you; abhihitā — explained/uttered; sāṅkhye — in the Sāṅkhya (discriminative) teaching; buddhiḥ — intellect/understanding; jñāna‑yoge — in the knowledge-path; tu — but/and; imām — this; śṛṇu — hear; upadekṣyāmi — I will instruct; buddhi‑yogam — the yoga of the intellect/way of wise discernment; tayā — by that; vṛtta‑uccheda‑cetsu — for the mind’s course‑cutting (cutting off of mental modes). (Literal sense:) This intelligence has been declared to you in Sāṅkhya; now hear this knowledge in yoga. I will teach the intellect-yoga by which the course of (mis)conception in the mind is cut off.
verses.context: Krishna closes the immediate sequence by distinguishing Sāṅkhya (discriminative knowledge) and Yoga (applied discipline). Having given Arjuna analytical reasons for action, he turns to a practical path—buddhi‑yoga—that severs the habitual mental patterns causing doubt and paralysis. Narratively, this shifts from ethical exhortation to an instructional method: refine the intellect and practice detachment so that right action flows without obsessive attachment or confusion. Philosophically, it synthesizes knowledge and action: insight (jñāna) must translate into disciplined, intelligent action (yoga) to uproot delusion.
verses.explanation: Insight matters only when it enables movement. Knowledge that does not lead to action remains incomplete.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse addresses the cognitive mechanism of indecision: knowing principles (Sāṅkhya) is insufficient unless coupled with disciplined application (Yoga) that interrupts maladaptive thought loops. Psychologically, buddhi‑yoga fosters metacognitive control—observing and redirecting rumination and fear-driven narratives. In modern settings, it recommends combining clear values-based insight with practices (mindfulness, cognitive reappraisal, action plans) that break avoidance patterns. The result is decisive, grounded action unclouded by obsessive worrying or paralysis by analysis.

verses.sanskrit: नेहाभिक्रमनाशोऽस्ति प्रत्यवायो न विद्यते | स्वल्पमेध्यात्मनां विद्वान्भावो न धीरो महत् ||
verses.transliteration: Ne hābhikramanāśo 'sti pratyavāyo na vidyate | svalpa-medhyātmānāṃ vidvān bhāvo na dhīro mahat ||
verses.translation: neha — here; abhikramana — withdrawal/retrogression; nāśaḥ — destruction/loss; asti — is not. pratyavāyaḥ — of complete loss; na — not; vidyate — exists. svalpa — small; medhā‑ātmānām — of those of little intelligence; vidvān — (one) learned/knowing; bhāvaḥ — state/attainment; na — not; dhīraḥ — steady/firm; mahat — great. (Literal:) "Here no retrogressive loss exists; total loss does not occur. For persons of slight intelligence, the wise state does not (remain) great/firm."
verses.context: This verse occurs in the middle of Krishna’s second-chapter instruction to Arjuna, after Arjuna has despaired and Krishna begins to teach the nature of self, duty and steady action. Philosophically it reassures that sincere striving in the path of knowledge and right action is not wasted: effort has effect even if outcomes aren't immediately apparent. Narrative setting: Arjuna on the Kurukṣetra field, wavering; Krishna reassures him that spiritual progress compounds and does not vanish simply because one’s practice is partial or interrupted.
verses.explanation: Growth compounds quietly. Even incomplete effort leaves residue of learning.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically, the verse soothes fear of wasted effort and supports resilience: small, honest attempts accumulate into lasting change. For modern readers it reframes setbacks as increments, not annihilation of progress, reducing perfectionism and paralysis. In therapy or habit change, it encourages consistent practice over all-or-nothing thinking: even brief, imperfect attempts alter neural pathways. Practically, keep a record of small wins, normalize starts and stops, and recognize that persistence, not instantaneous mastery, secures durable growth.

verses.sanskrit: व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिर्एकेह कुरुनन्दन | बहुशाखा ह्यनन्ताश्च बुद्धयोऽव्यवसायिनाम् ||
verses.transliteration: Vyavasayātmikā buddhir ekeha kurunandana | bahu-śākhā hy anantāś ca buddhayo 'vyavasāyinām ||
verses.translation: vyavasāya-ātmikā — resolution-attached/intellect-of-steady-resolution; buddhir — the intellect; ekeha — in this (world)/here alone; kurunandana — O scion of the Kurus (Arjuna). bahu-śākhāḥ — many-branched; hi — indeed; anantāḥ — endless/many; ca — and; buddhayaḥ — intellects/disposed minds; avyavasāyinām — of those without steady purpose. (Literal:) "Firm-resolutioned intellect exists here alone, O Kurunandana; the intellects of the irresolute are indeed many-branched and endless."
verses.context: Krishna contrasts two types of intellect after describing the nature of steady wisdom. He tells Arjuna that a determined, single-pointed resolve (vyavasāya) is necessary for steady action and spiritual progress, while those lacking such resolve have scattered minds with many branches of desire and distraction. In the battlefield narrative this is a counseling moment: Arjuna must cultivate focused resolve to perform his duty without being swayed by fear and attachment. Philosophically it underscores one-pointed practice as essential for self-mastery and clarity.
verses.explanation: Energy multiplies when direction is unified.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse highlights the cognitive cost of divided attention: the mind that repeatedly branches into desires cannot sustain deep work or moral resolve. Psychologically, cultivating vyavasāya means training attention, limiting options, and committing to a chosen path. Modern application includes using routines, removing distractions, and breaking goals into singular commitments (e.g., Pomodoro, priority lists). For therapists and coaches, it suggests building small, consistent practices to transform a scattered mind into one capable of steady, value-aligned action.

verses.sanskrit: भोगैश्चैव मनोरथैश्च पार्थ भोगैश्वर्यप्रसक्तानाम् | त्यागात्माभिरुचिरसंन्यस्तसत्त्वभिरपरिमार्जितम् ||
verses.transliteration: Bhogaiś caiva manorathaiś ca pārtha bhogaiśvaryaprasaktānām | tyāgātma‑bhir rucira‑sannyasta‑sattvabhir aparimārjitam ||
verses.translation: bhogaiś ca — by enjoyments and; eva — indeed; manorathaiḥ ca — by mental-desires also; pārtha — O son of Pṛthā (Arjuna); bhogaiśvaryaprasaktānām — of those attached to enjoyment and to sovereignty/wealth; tyāga‑ātma‑bhih — by renouncing-self (by self-directed renunciation); rucira — quickly/soon (or "easily"); sannyasta‑sattvabhiḥ — by purified beings who have abandoned (attachments); aparimārjitam — (becomes) untarnished/cleansed. (Literal:) "Those attached to pleasures and to riches, O Pārtha, by pleasures and mental-desires; by self-renunciation, (they become) quickly cleansed by the purified renunciates."
verses.context: Here Krishna warns Arjuna about the influence of sensual enjoyment and wealth on one’s intellect and steadiness. In the larger dialogue, Krishna differentiates between those whose minds are bound by external pleasures and power and those who have purified themselves through renunciation and discipline. This verse is part of a sequence that urges Arjuna to see how attachment to transient rewards distorts judgement and prevents steady practice. The counsel is both ethical and pragmatic: freedom requires detachment from cravings.
verses.explanation: Pleasure becomes a distraction when it replaces purpose.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically, attachment to sensory reward and status creates reactive patterns: decisions are driven by craving and fear rather than values. The verse recommends disciplined renunciation—not as ascetic withdrawal but as selective disengagement from impulses that derail goals. Modern application includes digital minimalism, financial restraint, and boundary-setting to reduce hedonic capture. Clinically, it supports interventions that shift reward contingencies (behavioral activation) and cultivate intrinsic motivation, allowing clearer priorities and sustained well‑being.

verses.sanskrit: कर्मण्येवाधिकारस्ते मा फलेषु कदाचन । मा कर्मफलहेतुर्भूर्मा ते सङ्गोऽस्त्वकर्मणि ॥
verses.transliteration: Karmaṇy eva adhikāras te mā phaleṣu kadācana | mā karma‑phalhetu r bhūr mā te saṅgo 'stvakarmaṇi ||
verses.translation: karmaṇi — in action; eva — certainly; adhikāraḥ — the right/duty; te — yours; mā — do not; phaleṣu — to the fruits; kadācana — at any time. mā — do not; karma‑phalhetuḥ — be the cause for the fruit of action; bhūḥ — become; mā — do not; te — your; saṅgaḥ — attachment; asti — be; akarmaṇi — in inaction. (Literal:) "Your right is only to the action; never to its fruits. Let not the fruit of action be your motive; nor let your attachment be to inaction."
verses.context: This is one of the Bhagavad Gita's most cited verses, spoken early in Krishna’s instruction. It responds to Arjuna’s paralysis about killing kin by clarifying duty: one must perform one’s prescribed action (especially in the social and moral role) without attachment to outcomes. Narratively, Krishna frames action as obligation rather than as a means to selfish ends. Philosophically, the verse anchors karma-yoga: ethical, dutiful action combined with inner detachment cultivates equanimity and reduces bondage to results.
verses.explanation: The burden of results often paralyzes effort. Krishna redirects attention to responsibility rather than reward. This is not detachment from effort, but detachment from obsession. Action becomes steadier when outcomes are released.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically, this teaches decoupling self‑worth from outcomes: focus on effort and responsibility, not external validation. It combats performance anxiety and procrastination driven by fear of failure. Practically, adopt process-oriented goals, measurable habits, and acceptance of uncertainty. In leadership and therapy, encourage responsibility without outcome‑fixation: do the work you can control, let go of what you cannot. This reduces rumination, preserves resilience after setbacks, and sustains long‑term engagement with purposeful activity.

verses.sanskrit: योगस्थः कुरु कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा धनञ्जय । सिद्ध्यसिद्ध्योः समो भूत्वा समत्वं योग उच्यते ॥
verses.transliteration: yogasthaḥ kuru karmāṇi saṅgaṁ tyaktvā dhanañjaya | siddhy-asiddhyoḥ samo bhūtvā samatvaṁ yoga ucyate ||
verses.translation: yogasthaḥ — established-in-yoga; kuru — do; karmāṇi — actions; saṅgam — attachment; tyaktvā — having-abandoned; dhanañjaya — O Dhanañjaya; siddhi-asiddhyoḥ — of success-and-failure; samo — equal; bhūtvā — having-become; samatvam — equanimity; yogaḥ — yoga; ucyate — is-called.
verses.context: Situated early in Krishna's instruction to Arjuna on the battlefield of Kurukṣetra, this verse follows the turn from Arjuna's despair to practical counsel. Krishna defines the characteristic of one established in yoga: performing one's prescribed duty without clinging to outcomes. Philosophically it connects karman (action), vairagya (dispassion), and sama (evenness) into a single praxis: inner steadiness (yogastha) that permits full engagement in the world while transcending the emotional sway of success and failure.
verses.explanation: Balance is not withdrawal but composure. This verse encourages acting fully while remaining inwardly stable.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically, this verse prescribes decoupling identity from results: it trains the ego to locate worth in right effort, not in external validation. Practically, it reduces anxiety about outcomes and the burnout from overinvesting emotionally in tasks. In modern life one can apply this by committing to process-focused goals (daily practice, quality work) while using mindfulness to notice attachment. Over time, this builds resilience and steadiness—acting responsibly without compulsive reactivity when outcomes vary.

verses.sanskrit: बुद्धियुक्तो जहातीह उभे सुकृतदुष्कृते । तस्यात्मा विनिर्भुक्तो विषयैर्वियोगेन मनः ॥
verses.transliteration: buddhi-yukto jahāti iha ubhe sukṛta-duṣkṛte | tasya ātmā vinirbhukto viṣayair viyogena manaḥ ||
verses.translation: buddhi-yuktaḥ — one-endowed-with-discriminative-intellect; jahāti — casts-off/abandons; iha — here/in this life; ubhe — both; sukṛta — good-deeds/results; duṣkṛte — ill-deeds/results; tasya — of him; ātmā — the self; vinirbhuktaḥ — freed/released; viṣayaiḥ — from sense-objects; viyogenā — by separation; manaḥ — the mind.
verses.context: In the flow of Krishna's teaching on karma-yoga, this verse explicates the practical fruit of integrating buddhi (discernment) with action. Krishna is answering Arjuna's fear of consequences and moral anxiety, teaching that a person who acts with right discrimination (buddhi-yukta) surrenders attachment to both praise and blame. Philosophically it ties gnosis (jñāna) to ethical action: discernment cleanses the actor's relation to sense-objects so that the mind is liberated even while living and acting in the world.
verses.explanation: Wisdom dissolves obsession with moral scoring.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse emphasizes cognitive reframing: when decisions are guided by clear, mature judgment, the mind relinquishes binary moral anxiety about 'good' and 'bad' results. Psychologically, it reduces rumination and moral perfectionism by strengthening meta-cognition—observing motives and outcomes without over-identifying. In practice, cultivate decision rituals (pause, clarify values, act), then disengage from obsessive outcome-checking. This fosters mental freedom, allowing purposeful action without paralysis from fear of making mistakes or craving credit.

verses.sanskrit: दुःखेष्वनुद्विग्नमनाः सुखेषु विगतस्पृहः । वीतरागभयक्रोधः स्थितधीर्मुनिरुच्यते ॥
verses.transliteration: duḥkheṣv anudvigna-manāḥ sukhēṣu vigata-spṛhaḥ | vītarāga-bhaya-krodhaḥ sthita-dhīr munir ucyate ||
verses.translation: duḥkheṣu — in sufferings; anudvigna-manāḥ — minds-not-agitated; sukhēṣu — in pleasures; vigata-spṛhaḥ — free-from-craving; vīta-rāga-bhaya-krodhaḥ — freed-from-attachment, fear, anger; sthita-dhīḥ — firm-minded/steadied-intellect; muniḥ ucyate — is called a sage.
verses.context: This verse follows Krishna’s delineation of characteristics of a steady (sthita-dhī) person. He contrasts reactive minds with the sage-like temperament that remains balanced across life's polarities. Narratively, Krishna is counseling Arjuna to adopt an inner poise that neither collapses in sorrow nor inflates in pleasure. Philosophically it codifies an ethical psychology: liberation is measured by freedom from craving, fear, and anger, and by the calm endurance of difficulty along with disinterest in mere sensory gratification.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically this verse maps emotional regulation: a mature mind neither panics under pain nor clings to pleasure. It prescribes reducing three core drivers of distress—attachment, fear, anger—so decision-making becomes steady. In modern therapy terms, practice exposure to discomfort, label emotions nonjudgmentally, and reduce reactivity through breath and cognitive distancing. Over time, the capacity to experience sorrow without disintegration and happiness without dependency promotes resilience, clearer priorities, and healthier relationships.

verses.sanskrit: ध्यानयतो विषयान्पुंसः सङ्गस्तेषूपजायते । सङ्गात्सञ्जायते कामः कामात्क्रोधोऽभिजायते ॥
verses.transliteration: dhyāyato viṣayān puṁsaḥ saṅgas teṣu upajāyate | saṅgāt sañjāyate kāmaḥ kāmāt krodho 'bhijāyate ||
verses.translation: dhyāyataḥ — by repeatedly-thought-about; viṣayān — sense-objects; puṁsaḥ — of a person; saṅgaḥ — attachment; teṣu — to them; upajāyate — arises; saṅgāt — from attachment; sañjāyate — is produced; kāmaḥ — desire; kāmāt — from desire; krodhaḥ — anger; abhijāyate — is born.
verses.context: Krishna here traces the psychological chain that leads from attention to suffering: contemplation of sense-objects breeds attachment, attachment breeds desire, and desire, when frustrated, breeds anger. The teaching situates a simple cognitive-behavioral sequence within the moral cosmology of the Gita, showing how inner states escalate into powerful compulsions that bind the self. It is part of Krishna's broader project to show Arjuna how inner habits—where attention goes—determine bondage or freedom.
verses.explanation: What the mind repeatedly entertains quietly shapes behavior. Freedom begins with awareness of attention.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse is essentially an early cognitive model: sustained attention to stimuli creates attachment, which escalates to desire and then anger if thwarted. Psychologically, it highlights the role of purposive attention in habit formation and impulse control. Modern applications include mindfulness training to interrupt rumination, stimulus control to limit exposure, and cognitive restructuring to defuse craving. By redirecting attention and reducing repetitive mental rehearsal of urges, one weakens the chain that leads to compulsive behavior and emotional dysregulation.

verses.sanskrit: रागद्वेषवियुक्तैः स्थितप्रज्ञैः यस्य शान्तिं शाश्वतम् अचलम् प्राप्तः।
verses.transliteration: rāga-dveṣa-viyuktaiḥ sthita-prajñaiḥ yasya śāntiṁ śāśvatam acalam prāptaḥ.
verses.translation: rāga-dveṣa-viyuktaiḥ — by those freed from attachment and aversion; sthita-prajñaiḥ — by the steadywise (those of firm wisdom); yasya — whose; śāntim — peace; śāśvatam — eternal; acalam — immoveable; prāptaḥ — is attained.
verses.context: In the second chapter of the Bhagavad Gita, Krishna is instructing Arjuna on the nature of the self and the means to steadiness of mind. After describing how desire and anger cloud judgment (2.62–2.63), Krishna explains that a person of steady wisdom, who is free from raga (attachment) and dveṣa (aversion), attains an enduring, immovable peace. This verse places ethical detachment and cognitive stability at the heart of spiritual freedom and introduces the psychological disposition (sthita-prajña) ideal for action without bondage.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically, this verse pinpoints a resilient inner equilibrium arising when reactive attractions and aversions are reduced. Modern application: cultivations like cognitive distancing, acceptance, and values-aligned action reduce compulsive wants/aversions, producing sustainable calm. Rather than eliminating feelings, it trains the mind to avoid being driven reflexively by them, enabling deliberate choices under stress. This steadiness (sthita-prajñatā) supports clearer perception, reduced rumination, and greater long-term well-being, useful in therapy, leadership, and personal decision-making.
verses.explanation: When extremes soften, clarity emerges naturally.

verses.sanskrit: प्रसादे सर्वदुःखानां हानिर्वर्तते मनसः शुद्धये।
verses.transliteration: prasāde sarva-duḥkhānāṁ hānir vartate manasaḥ śuddhaye.
verses.translation: prasāde — by tranquillity/grace/serenity; sarva-duḥkhānām — of all sufferings; hāniḥ — the destruction/removal; vartate — occurs; manasaḥ — of the mind; śuddhaye — for purification/clearing.
verses.context: Following the description of how ignorance and disturbed thinking bind one to suffering, Krishna indicates that when the mind attains a state of serenity or clarity (prasāda), the accumulation of mental suffering is undone. In the Gita’s practical teaching, this connects inner calm with functional purification: a settled mind ceases to generate the chains of desire and aversion that produce ongoing distress, thereby enabling right action and insight.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse highlights that inner calm functions therapeutically: when the mind is steady and clarified, habitual suffering loses its hold. In contemporary terms, practices that reduce hyperarousal—mindfulness, breath regulation, cognitive restructuring—create ‘prasāda’ that allows emotional wounds to resolve and cognitive distortions to drop away. The result is not mere suppression but a transformative clearing that reveals choices previously hidden by reactivity, improving mental health, decision-making, and relationships.
verses.explanation: Sustained calm heals what effort cannot.

verses.sanskrit: न हि कश्चित्त्यकर्मणि जातु त्वमकर्मकृत्; कर्मण्येवाधिकारस्ते मा फलेषु कदाचन।
verses.transliteration: na hi kaścit tya-karmaṇi jātu tvam akarma-kṛt; karmaṇy eva adhikāras te mā phaleṣu kadācana.
verses.translation: na — not; hi — indeed; kaścit — anyone; tya-karmaṇi — in inactivity (or in being without activity); jātu — ever; tu — but; tvam — you; akarma-kṛt — doer-of-no-action (become someone who does no action); karmaṇi — in action; eva — certainly; adhikāras te — is your province/responsibility; mā — never; phaleṣu — in the fruits/results; kadācana — at any time.
verses.context: In chapter 3 Krishna addresses Arjuna’s confusion about action (karma) and renunciation (sannyāsa). This verse emphasizes that complete inaction is impossible; even the body and mind function, and one must perform one’s duty. Hence Arjuna’s right is to act (karma), not to cling to outcomes. It frames the central Gita teaching: perform prescribed duties dispassionately, focusing on responsible action rather than attachment to results.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically, the verse dispels magical thinking that one can escape responsibility by passive avoidance. Avoidance itself is an action with consequences. Modern application: embrace agency—focus on what you can control (effort, choices), not uncertain outcomes. This supports behavioral activation in therapy, reduces procrastination, and fosters resilience. By accepting responsibility for appropriate actions while detaching from results, one reduces anxiety about outcomes and cultivates stable motivation and ethical engagement.
verses.explanation: Even avoidance is a form of action. This verse encourages conscious engagement instead of denial.

verses.sanskrit: यस्त्वेन्द्रियाणि मनसा नियम्यारभतेऽर्जुन आत्मैवात्मानं वेत्ति ततो बुद्धिमात्मवत्त्वे।
verses.transliteration: yas tv endriyāṇi manasā niyamyārabhate 'rjuna ātmaivāt mānaṃ vetti tato buddhim ātmavat tveva.
verses.translation: yas — he who; tu — indeed; endriyāṇi — the senses; manasā — with the mind; niyamya — having restrained; ārabhate — begins (to act); 'arjuna — O Arjuna; ātma — the self; eva — indeed; ātma-anam — his own self (recognizes); vetti — knows; tataḥ — therefore; buddhim — discrimination/wisdom; ātma-vat — as equal to self; tve — indeed (emphatic).
verses.context: In the discourse on self-control and duty, Krishna tells Arjuna that those who restrain the senses by the mind and act without being led by sense-gratification gain true self-knowledge. The verse connects disciplined regulation of inputs (senses) with a transformation of understanding: when one treats the self as the guiding reference (ātma), one attains rightly ordered judgment (buddhi) and acts from steady wisdom. It prescribes inner governance as prerequisite for ethical, effective action.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse underscores the therapeutic power of self-regulation: training attention and moderating sensory impulses cultivates clearer self-awareness and wise judgment. Modern practices (mindfulness, impulse-control training, habit design) mirror this: by regulating stimuli and responses, one reduces impulsivity and aligns behavior with values. Psychologically, it shifts identity from reactive to reflective selfhood, enabling intentional choices, better concentration, and emotional stability—skills valuable for mental health, productivity, and moral responsibility.

verses.sanskrit:
नियतं कुरु कर्म त्वं कर्म ज्यायो ह्यकर्मणः ।
शरीरयात्रापि च ते न प्रसिध्येत् अकर्मणः ॥
verses.transliteration: niyataṁ kuru karma tvam karma jyāyo hi akarmaṇaḥ | śarīra-yātrā api ca te na prasiddhyed akarmaṇaḥ ||
verses.translation: niyatam — regulated/prescribed; kuru — do; karma — action/duty; tvam — you; karma — action; jyāyaḥ — superior/better; hi — indeed; akarmaṇaḥ — than non-action; śarīra-yātrā — bodily maintenance/the journey of the body; api — even; ca — also; te — for you; na — not; prasiddhyet — will be accomplished/succeed; akarmaṇaḥ — by non-action. (Literal:) "Do your prescribed duty; indeed action is superior to non-action; even the maintenance of the body for you will not be accomplished by non-action."
verses.context: In the battlefield dialogue Krishna addresses Arjuna’s paralysis about acting. Here Krishna gives a practical injunction: performing one’s prescribed, regulated duty (niyata karma) is necessary. He contrasts action with inaction, arguing that refraining from action will not even sustain the body’s necessities. Philosophically this anchors karma-yoga: ethical, responsible action performed without attachment is a means to keep the social and bodily order and to progress spiritually. The verse occurs as Krishna teaches duty over passivity in the broader discussion of selfless action.
verses.explanation: Stability often begins with simple, necessary action.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically, this verse combats avoidance and frozen indecision: it urges commencing practicable, regulated tasks rather than waiting for perfect readiness. In modern life, following a steady routine—work, self-care, commitments—sustains physical and social life and prevents erosion of capability. It reframes action not as mere busyness but as the disciplined support structure for personal integrity. When anxiety or nihilism tempts withdrawal, this teaching promotes incremental, duty-centered engagement to rebuild agency and protect wellbeing.

verses.sanskrit:
यज्ञार्थात्कर्मणोऽन्यत्र लोकोऽयं कर्मबन्धनः ।
तदर्थं कर्म कौन्तेय सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा करोति यः ॥
verses.transliteration: yajñārthāt karmaṇo 'nyatra loko 'yaṁ karma-bandhanaḥ | tad-artham karma kaunteya saṅgaṁ tyaktvā karoti yaḥ ||
verses.translation: yajña-arthāt — for the sake of the sacrificial/communal offering; karmaṇo — of actions; anyatra — otherwise/elsewhere; lokaḥ — the world; ayam — this; karma-bandhanaḥ — is bondage through action; tad-artham — for that purpose; karma — action; kaunteya — O son of Kunti; saṅgam — attachment/association; tyaktvā — having abandoned; karoti — does; yaḥ — who. (Literal:) "Action is for sacrifice; otherwise this world is the bondage of actions. For that purpose, O Kaunteya, whoever acts having abandoned attachment does (action)."
verses.context: Following the injunction to act (3.8), Krishna explains why actions should be performed as offerings (yajña) — not for selfish fruit. He presents a socio-cosmic rationale: when actions are done as part of a sacrificial, relational economy (yajña), they support the world; when done for selfish ends, they bind the actor in karma. This situates karma-yoga within a communal, ritual-philosophical frame: duty done as mutual support dissolves personal attachment and reduces bondage.
verses.explanation: Effort disconnected from meaning drains vitality.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically the verse reframes motivation: if actions are done as contributions to a larger good rather than purely self-centred gains, they lessen compulsive attachment and resentment. In modern application, turning work into service—seeing tasks as supporting family, community, or purpose—reduces burnout and the sense of futility. Letting go of reward-focused attachment (tyaktvā saṅgaṁ) helps maintain equanimity when outcomes are uncertain, fostering sustainable engagement and healthier relationships between agency and consequence.

verses.sanskrit:
एवं प्रवर्तितं चक्रं मया स्थितं जगदेकम् ।
मनुष्येभ्यः कारणं भूतानां न हि स्मरम् ॥
verses.transliteration: evaṁ pravartitaṁ cakraṁ mayā sthitaṁ jagad ekam | manuṣyebhyaḥ kāraṇaṁ bhūtānāṁ na hi smaram ||
verses.translation: evam — thus; pravartitam — set in motion/caused to operate; cakram — the wheel/cycle; mayā — by me; sthitam — placed/established; jagat — the world; ekam — one/unique; manuṣyebhyaḥ — for mankind/humans; kāraṇaṁ — a cause/reason; bhūtānām — of beings; na — not; hi — indeed; smaram — remember/recall. (Literal:) "Thus I have established the wheel of the world; it is not remembered by beings as the cause for humans."
verses.context: This verse appears amid Krishna’s exposition of how actions and social duties are interwoven into the world’s functioning. He describes the cyclical, divinely-ordered operation (wheel) by which duties, sacrifices, and sustenance proceed. The verse highlights that beings generally fail to perceive the underlying ordering cause and instead become deluded about agency and results. Philosophically it underscores ignorance about the systemic source of social order and the importance of right understanding for proper action.
verses.detailed_explanation: On a psychological level, this verse addresses attribution biases: people often overlook systemic causes and over-attribute events to individual actors. In contemporary terms, it invites awareness that institutions, roles, and interdependencies enable personal functioning. Recognising systemic 'wheels' reduces self-blame and ego inflation, encouraging responsibility without false ownership. Practically, it supports collaborative problem-solving, public-minded action, and policies that stabilise shared life—promoting mental health by shifting from solitary burden to collective stewardship.

verses.sanskrit:
कर्मणैव हि संसिद्धिं स्थिता जनकादयः ।
हत्वा न विजानन्ति लोकान्येव परस्परम् ॥
verses.transliteration: karmaṇai va hi saṁsiddhiṁ sthatā janakādayaḥ | hatvā na vijānanti lokān yeva parasparam ||
verses.translation: karmaṇai — by actions; eva — indeed; hi — certainly; saṁsiddhim — success/perfection; sthatā — attained/achieved; janaka-ādayaḥ — Janaka and others (exemplars); hatvā — having performed/achieved (or 'thus'); na — not; vijānanti — understand/know; lokān — the worlds/people; yeva — only; parasparam — mutually/among themselves. (Literal:) "Indeed, by actions alone have exemplars like Janaka attained perfection; by (their) action the people mutually do not perceive otherwise."
verses.context: Here Krishna points to historical exemplars (like King Janaka) whose spiritual and societal perfection came through active engagement and duty. He counters the idea that renunciation alone, without right action, leads to completion. The verse reinforces the theme that action, performed rightly and as duty, produces social stability and personal spiritual development. It is placed in Krishna’s broader argument that ethical action sustains both world-order and inner growth.
verses.explanation: Withdrawal is not the only path to peace.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically, invoking exemplars reduces isolation and offers models for constructive agency: seeing leaders attain fulfillment through duty encourages emulation. Modern application: professionals, parents, and citizens can find meaning in committed action rather than escapism. Recognising that disciplined participation strengthens community and individual maturity helps combat apathy. It supports resilience: consistent contribution, even amid uncertainty, builds competence, social trust, and a sense of purpose that protects against despair.

verses.sanskrit:
यद् यद् आचरति श्रेष्ठः लोकस्तदनुवर्तते ।
स यत्प्रमाणं कुरुते लोकस्तदअनुवर्तते ॥
verses.transliteration:
yad yad ācarati śreṣṭhaḥ lokas tad anuvartate |
sa yat pramāṇaṁ kurute lokas tad anuvartate ||
verses.translation: Whatever whatever does the excellent-one, the people that follows; That which measure/standard he makes, the people that follow.
verses.context: In the middle of Krishna's teaching on karma-yoga in the battlefield, he highlights the social and moral influence of exemplary persons. After explaining how action and motivation bind beings, Krishna points out that those perceived as noble or authoritative set patterns others imitate; thus leaders' conduct shapes collective behavior. The verse answers Arjuna's concerns about personal duty by situating individual action within a social moral ecology: one's personal practice becomes a model that others habitually follow, for good or ill.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically, this verse underlines social learning: humans mirror salient models to form norms and habits. When an admired person acts, observers internalize cues that shape their choices, often unconsciously. Modern application: leaders, parents, teachers and public figures must attend to how their behavior becomes a template—small acts accumulate into culture. For therapy and coaching, fostering adaptive role models and deliberate micro-behaviors helps rewire habits. Ethically, it calls for integrity: personal discipline functions as social intervention by reducing ambiguity and modelling constructive responses under stress.

verses.sanskrit:
प्रकृतेः क्रियाणि गुणैः कर्माणि सर्वशः ।
अहङ्कारविमूढात्मा कर्ताहं इति मन्यते ॥
verses.transliteration:
prakṛteḥ kriyāṇi guṇaiḥ karmāṇi sarvaśaḥ |
ahaṅkāra-vimūḍhātmā kartāaham iti manyate ||
verses.translation: From nature (prakṛti) actions (kriyāṇi) by the qualities (guṇaiḥ) are performed all (sarvaśaḥ); Ego-deluded-self (ahaṅkāra-vimūḍhātmā) thinks 'I-am-the-doer' (kartāaham iti manyate).
verses.context: Krishna explains the mechanics of agency within the framework of prakṛti (nature) and guṇas (modes). Responding to Arjuna's confusion about doership, Krishna teaches that bodily and mental actions arise from the interplay of sattva, rajas and tamas within the field of prakṛti; the embodied self, clouded by ego, mistakenly appropriates authorship. This locates responsibility without metaphysical solipsism: actions occur through conditioned nature, yet the sense of 'I' obscures impersonal causal processes.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse exposes the psychological source of the 'I did it' illusion: habits and dispositions (the guṇas) generate behavior, while the ego claims credit. Clinically, it reframes responsibility—acknowledging conditioning reduces shame and enables skillful change. In modern practice, recognizing triggers, reward patterns, and automaticity empowers targeted interventions (habit reversal, cognitive restructuring). Ethically, it supports compassionate accountability: we cannot deny consequences, but we can transform conditioning through sustained practice, environment design, and reflective self-inquiry to diminish ego-driven reactivity.

verses.sanskrit:
मयि सर्वाणि कर्माणि सन्न्यस्य आध्यात्मचेतसा ।
निराशीर्निर्ममो भूत्वा युध्यस्व विगतज्वरः ॥
verses.transliteration:
mayi sarvāṇi karmāṇi sannyasya adhyātma-cetasā |
nirāśīr nirmamo bhūtvā yudhyasva vigata-jvaraḥ ||
verses.translation: In me all actions (sarvāṇi karmāṇi) putting down (sannyasya) with spiritual-mind (adhyātma-cetasā); without expectation (nirāśī), without-attachment being (nirmamaḥ bhūtvā), fight (yudhyasva) free-from-fever (vigata-jvaraḥ).
verses.context: Krishna instructs Arjuna on how to perform duty without bondage. After describing how actions bind through desire and ego, Krishna prescribes a stance of internal surrender: offer all acts to the Divine (to Krishna), maintain an inner spiritual focus, relinquish desire for fruits and personal ownership, then perform one's duty calmly. This is the practical core of karma-yoga: active engagement combined with inner renunciation, especially pertinent for Arjuna as a warrior obliged to fight.
verses.explanation: Ownership creates tension; release restores flow.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically, the verse prescribes decentering the ego and reframing motivation: when action is offered to a larger purpose, anxiety about outcomes recedes. Modern application includes stress-reduction by focusing on process rather than result (flow states, values-driven work). Practically, it advises cognitive reappraisal—shift from ‘I must control outcome’ to ‘I will do my part with integrity.’ This reduces performance pressure and enhances resilience. For leaders and practitioners, cultivating purpose and relinquishing rigid attachment to results sustains consistent, compassionate action under strain.

verses.sanskrit: सदृशं चेष्टते स्वस्य प्रियमात्मनः ।
verses.transliteration: sadṛśaṁ ceṣṭate svasyāḥ priyam ātmanaḥ |
verses.translation: Similar (sadṛśam) behaves/acts (ceṣṭate) of one's own (svasyāḥ) what-is-dear (priyam) to the self (ātmanaḥ).
verses.context: Placed amid Krishna's account of how nature and habit determine behavior, this verse underscores that beings tend to act in ways aligned with their own inclinations and what they find satisfying. Krishna emphasizes that individuals gravitate toward what they consider dear or pleasant, shaped by their inner constitution and previous conditioning. This observation explains why different people choose divergent paths and resist reform unless deeper attractions and habits are addressed.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse points to the pull of preference: people repeatedly choose what feels rewarding, even if harmful. Psychologically, cravings and conditioned rewards guide behavior; acceptance without self-condemnation is the first step to change. Modern interventions—motivation interviewing, habit-design, values clarification—work by aligning healthier choices with what the person truly values, or by changing reward contingencies. Practically, recognize your attractions, restructure the environment, and cultivate alternative sources of satisfaction so that wise choices become easier and habitual impulses lose their automatic power.

verses.sanskrit: श्रेयान् स्वधर्मो विगुणः परधर्मात् स्वनुष्ठितात् ।
verses.transliteration: śreyān sva-dharmo viguṇaḥ para-dharmāt svanuṣṭhitāt
verses.translation: śreyān — better/auspicious; sva-dharmo — one's own duty; viguṇaḥ — though with faults/defective; para-dharmāt — than the duty of another; svanuṣṭhitāt — when performed (by oneself).
verses.context: In the Bhakti and Karma context of the Gita, Krishna addresses Arjuna who is tempted to abandon his Kshatriya duty because of compassion and fear. Here Krishna insists that adherence to one's own prescribed duty (svadharma), even if imperfect, is superior to adopting another's duty (paradharma) that might be performed perfectly. The statement counters pride-based imitation and promotes moral authenticity: each person’s role in the social-spiritual order has a corrective and purificatory function that must be honored for proper growth.
verses.explanation: Imitation creates instability. Authentic effort sustains growth.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse speaks to the psychological importance of owning one’s responsibilities rather than envying others’ roles. When we chase someone else’s path because it looks easier or nobler, we erode self-trust and create identity-conflict. Psychologically, committing to imperfect personal duty builds competence, reduces anxiety from social comparison, and fosters integrity. In modern terms, it counsels acceptance of one’s vocational or relational duties, encouraging steady effort over flashy imitation. Growth arises from persistent practice in one’s sphere, not from adopting another’s script.

verses.sanskrit: अथ केन प्रयुक्तोऽयम् पापं चरति पुरुषः ।
verses.transliteration: atha kena prayukto 'yam pāpaṁ carati puruṣaḥ
verses.translation: atha — now/then; kena — by what/through what; prayuktaḥ — having been driven/impelled; ayam — this; pāpam — sinful/evil (action); carati — does he perform; puruṣaḥ — the person/man.
verses.context: Following the counsel on duty and action, Arjuna (or the inquiring mind) asks a psychological question: if duty and reason counsel one thing, why do people still commit acts they recognize as wrong? This is the Gita moving from normative teaching to the inner dynamics of vice. Krishna has just outlined the chain from senses to desire; here the dialogue turns to causation of wrongdoing. The verse frames the problem of akarma (contrary action) as one of inner compulsion rather than mere ignorance.
verses.detailed_explanation: This line probes the felt experience of acting against better judgment — a core issue in psychology. It emphasizes that harmful acts often follow an internal compulsion: impulses, conditioned habits, and misidentified gratifications. Modern therapy frames this as automaticity, cue-response loops, and maladaptive reward learning. Recognizing the mechanism — 'by what am I driven?' — lets one introduce interventions (mindful awareness, habit-reversal, environment design) to break the chain and restore volitional agency over behavior.

verses.sanskrit: इन्द्रियाणि पराण्याहुरिन्द्रियभ्यः परं मनः । मनसश्च परं बुद्धिर्बुद्धेः परं तत्र अहम् ।
verses.transliteration: indriyāṇi parāṇy āhur indriyebhyaḥ paraṁ manaḥ | manasaś ca paraṁ buddhir buddheḥ paraṁ tatra aham
verses.translation: indriyāṇi — the senses (sense-objects/working faculties); parāṇi — superior/higher (plural); āhuḥ — they say; indriyebhyaḥ — than the sense-organs; param — higher; manaḥ — is the mind; manasaḥ — than the mind; tu — but; param — higher; buddhir — is the intellect/discriminative faculty; buddheḥ — than the intellect; param — higher; tatra — there; aham — I/self (the soul).
verses.context: Krishna here maps an inner hierarchy: sense-objects and senses, mind, intellect, and finally the Self. He explains how impulses can rise from external sensory contact through successive layers, culminating in identification with the ‘I’. This psychological anatomy helps explain how desire forms and why self-mastery requires addressing successive levels — not only behavior but also the mind and the discriminating intellect — to reach the stable center (ātman).
verses.explanation: Unchecked desire moves upward, consuming agency.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse gives a dimensional model of impulse formation: raw sensory stirrings → mind (emotional response) → intellect (discernment) → sense of self. Psychologically, it shows why interventions at only one level fail: cravings arise from sensory triggers, are amplified by rumination, and become entrenched when the self identifies with them. Modern application: interrupting the chain — via stimulus control, cognitive reappraisal, or self-observing awareness — weakens compulsions and restores autonomy over choices.

verses.sanskrit: एवं बुद्धेः परां बुद्ध्वा बुद्धिमान् मनो गृह्यते । मनो बुध्येः परं तु प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता स्यात् ।
verses.transliteration: evaṁ buddheḥ parāṁ buddhvā buddhimān mano gṛhyate | mano buddheḥ paraṁ tu prajñā pratiṣṭhitā syāt
verses.translation: evam — thus/in this way; buddheḥ — by (or of) the intellect; parām — supreme; buddhvā — having known/comprehended; buddhimān — the wise person; manaḥ — the mind; gṛhyate — is held/controlled; mano — the mind; buddheḥ — than the intellect; paraṁ — higher; tu — but; prajñā — discriminative wisdom/steady understanding; pratiṣṭhitā — becomes established; syāt — may be/becomes.
verses.context: Continuing the inner-order teaching, Krishna explains the corrective path: by understanding the relative positions of mind and intellect, the learned can control the mind. When intelligence rightly apprehends its role, steady wisdom (prajñā) becomes established. This is prescriptive: not only does desire ascend a hierarchy, but disciplined discriminative understanding can reverse and stabilize mental life.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse emphasizes deliberate cultivation of discriminative insight to tame the mind. Psychologically, it parallels cognitive restructuring: when reason clarifies values and consequences, emotional reactivity diminishes and habits loosen. Applied today, it recommends training the intellect (through reflection, education, or therapy) to reframe cravings and anxieties, thereby anchoring steady judgment. The result is not suppression but an integrated, resilient mind able to choose aligned actions rather than react impulsively.

verses.sanskrit:
कर्मण्यकर्म यः पश्येत् अकर्मणि च कर्म यः ।
स बुद्धिमान् मनुष्येषु स युक्तः कृत्स्नकर्मकृत् ॥
verses.transliteration:
karmaṇy akarma yaḥ paśyet akarmaṇi ca karma yaḥ |
sa buddhimān manuṣeṣu sa yuktaḥ kṛtsna-karma-kṛt ||
verses.translation: karmaṇi — in action; akarma — non-action; yaḥ — who; paśyet — sees; akarmaṇi — in non-action; ca — and; karma — action; yaḥ — who; sa — he; buddhimān — wise/intelligent; manuṣeṣu — among humans; sa — he; yuktaḥ — established/steady; kṛtsna-karma-kṛt — having performed all actions. Literal: "Who sees non-action in action, and action in non-action — he is wise among men; he is established, the doer of all actions."
verses.context: On the Kurukṣetra battlefield Krishna expands on the subtle skill of discriminating reality within activity. Here Arjuna is being taught how to reconcile inner detachment with outer duties: action and apparent inaction are not mutually exclusive. Philosophically this verse sits within Krishna's discourse on jñāna (knowledge) and karma (action), showing how true insight transforms how one performs duties without being bound by their fruit. It responds to Arjuna's confusion about renunciation vs. engaged action and clarifies the integrated ideal of a wise agent.
verses.explanation: True action includes awareness. Motion without clarity exhausts.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically the verse describes mindful competence: a person learns to act from a centered awareness that is not enslaved by outcomes. This reduces anxiety and reactive behavior because actions are performed from clarity rather than compulsion. In modern life it advises doing responsibilities (work, care, projects) with full engagement while maintaining inner equipoise — neither obsessive attachment to results nor passive withdrawal. Practically, this looks like focused effort, acceptance of uncertainty, and steady performance without identity collapse when outcomes differ from expectation.

verses.sanskrit: त्यक्त्वा कर्मफलआसङ्गः नित्यतृप्तो निराशीर् यान्ति ब्रह्मनिर्वृत्तिम् ॥
verses.transliteration: tyaktvā karma-phala-āsangaḥ nitya-tṛpto nirāśīr yānti brahma-nivṛttiṁ ||
verses.translation: tyaktvā — having abandoned; karma-phala — the fruit of action; āsangaḥ — attachment; nitya — always; tṛptaḥ — satisfied; nirāśīḥ — without desire/expectation; yānti — they go; brahma-nivṛttiṁ — to the cessation/return in Brahman (liberation). Literal: "Having abandoned attachment to the fruit of action, ever satisfied and free from desire, one attains (goes to) the cessation/return in Brahman."
verses.context: Krishna continues instructing Arjuna on the fruitless nature of craving results. In the broader narrative this is part of the teaching that renunciation of fruit, not renunciation of duty, leads to inner freedom. Philosophically it links right action with detachment: giving up expectation and cultivating steady contentment moves the practitioner toward mokṣa (liberation). It situates the ethical task of acting without clinging within the path of spiritual emancipation, answering Arjuna's dilemma about action vs. withdrawal.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse tackles the modern psychology of reward-dependence and chronic seeking. Letting go of outcome-attachment reduces emotional volatility and compulsive striving. When satisfaction becomes internal (nitya-tṛpta), motivation arises from purpose rather than from external validation, decreasing stress and burnout. Practically, adopt process-focused goals, celebrate effort, and cultivate contentment practices (gratitude, self-checks) so you act responsibly yet are not destabilized by success or failure. Over time this fosters resilience and clearer long-term perspective.

verses.sanskrit:
श्रेयात् द्रव्यमयाद् यज्ञात् ज्ञानयज्ञोऽपरं परन्तप ।
अन्यत्र यज्ञः शरीरविनाशिनोऽऽर्थे करोति ॥
verses.transliteration:
śreyāt dravya-mayād yajñāt jñāna-yajño 'paraṁ parantapa |
anyatra yajñaḥ śarīra-vināśino 'rthe karoti ||
verses.translation: śreyāt — superior/better; dravya-mayāt — than one made of wealth/material; yajñāt — from sacrifice; jñāna-yajñaḥ — the sacrifice of knowledge; aparam — other/else; parantapa — O scorcher of foes (Arjuna, vocative); anyatra — elsewhere/otherwise; yajñaḥ — sacrifice; śarīra-vināśinaḥ — that which destroys the body; arthe — for the sake/purpose; karoti — makes/produces. Literal: "Better than a sacrifice composed of wealth is the sacrifice of knowledge, O Parantapa; otherwise (in other cases) a sacrifice produces destruction of the body for the sake (it is meant) to do so."
verses.context: In the discourse contrasting external ritual and inner wisdom, Krishna places jñāna-yajña (sacrifice of knowledge) above material offerings. The narrative context addresses ritual practitioners and Arjuna's confusion about the value of action and sacrifice. Philosophically, the verse distinguishes instrumental religious acts from transformative inner practices: sacrifices made only of material gains do not yield lasting purification, while knowledge-oriented sacrifice leads to true spiritual advancement. It highlights that rituals without insight may reinforce ego and bodily aims rather than liberation.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically this verse critiques performative acts devoid of understanding: ritual without insight can become hollow habit reinforcing identity and anxiety. The jñāna-yajña champions intentional learning, reflection, and ethical cognition as means of transformation. For modern life, it means prioritizing practices that change mindset (therapy, study, mindful reflection) over mere busywork. Replacing mechanical routines with reflective rituals (journaling, deliberate practice) fosters genuine growth and prevents exhaustion born of purposeless activity, aligning behavior with deeper values.

verses.sanskrit:
न हि ज्ञानेन सदृशं पवित्रमिह विद्यते ।
तत् स्वयमेव यज्ञार्थात् कर्मसमाधधाच्छरीरं ॥
verses.transliteration:
na hi jñānena sadṛśaṁ pavitram iha vidyate |
tat svayameva yajñārthāt karma-samādadhā ca śarīraṁ ||
verses.translation: na hi — not indeed; jñānena — by (transcendental) knowledge; sadṛśam — equal/similar; pavitram — pure/purifying; iha — in this (world); vidyate — exists. tat — that; svayameva — by itself; yajñārthāt — for the sake of sacrifice; karma — actions; samādadhā — having arranged/performed suitably; ca — and; śarīram — the body (contextually: for the body). Literal: "Indeed there is no purifier in this world equal to knowledge; therefore, having arranged/performed actions properly for the sake of sacrifice itself (one purifies) the body."
verses.context: Krishna emphasizes the supreme purifying power of jñāna (higher knowledge) over ritual acts. Within the battlefield dialogue he counsels Arjuna that true purification and transformation come from cogent self-knowledge and rightly oriented action (actions done as yajña). This verse underlines the earlier themes: knowledge complements and elevates action; actions performed for higher purpose (not egoic gain) become purificatory. It situates soteriology: knowledge catalyzes inner purity that rituals alone cannot accomplish.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse speaks to the central therapeutic insight that awareness transforms behavior more than external fixes. Knowledge here is introspective clarity — seeing habitual patterns, biases, and motivations — which purifies intentions and reduces harmful reactivity. Applied today, it recommends learning and reflection (psychotherapy, self-inquiry, education) as primary tools for change. When actions are redirected by insight and performed for shared or ethical aims rather than egoic reward, they become healing practices, improving mental health and social relationships.

verses.sanskrit: यदा यदा हि धर्मस्य ग्लानिर्भवति भारत। अभ्युत्थानम् अधर्मस्य तदात्मानं सृजाम्यहम्॥
verses.transliteration: Yadā yadā hi dharmasya glānir bhavati bhārata, abhyutthānam adharmasya tadā ātmaānaṃ sṛjāmy aham.
verses.translation: Whenever — whenever indeed of dharma the decline occurs, O Bharata; of adharma the uprising/overthrow — then myself I manifest/create.
verses.context: In the Kurukṣetra dialogue, Krishna explains why he takes divine birth repeatedly. Addressing Arjuna (referred to as 'Bhārata'), Krishna situates his incarnations within a cosmic moral economy: when righteous order (dharma) deteriorates and unrighteousness (adharma) rises, a corrective manifestation arises. This verse follows the teaching on the origin of divine knowledge and precedes the description of the forms and purposes of those incarnations, emphasizing restoration of balance rather than arbitrary intervention.
verses.explanation: Correction emerges when imbalance becomes unsustainable.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically this verse affirms that crises elicit transformation. When personal or social values erode (internal 'dharma' declines), the psyche either collapses or mobilizes corrective forces — courage, conscience, and decisive action — to restore balance. Modern application: recognize warning signs of moral drift (apathy, rationalization, entitlement) and intentionally cultivate restorative practices (ethical reflection, accountability, principled leadership). Rather than waiting for an external savior, one can become the agent of restoration by aligning choices with enduring principles and responding decisively to emergent injustice.

verses.sanskrit: वितरागभयक्रोधा मनमयाः मामुपासते। सर्वार्थपरित्यागिनो मामेकं शरणं व्रजते॥
verses.transliteration: Vitarāga-bhaya-krodhā man-mayā mām upāsate; sarvārtha-parityāgino mām ekaṃ śaraṇaṃ vrajate.
verses.translation: Those freed from attachment, fear and anger, with minds absorbed, worship Me; renouncing all objectives, they to Me alone take refuge.
verses.context: This verse describes the inner temperament and mode of devotion of sincere seekers. Krishna is characterizing categories of devotees: those whose minds are steady, free from attachment, fear and anger, who focus their consciousness on the divine, and those who renounce all worldly aims and take sole refuge in God. It situates devotion not as mere ritual but as a transformed psychological stance rooted in dispassion and surrender. The verse precedes and connects to points about how Krishna reciprocates according to the devotee's approach.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically, this verse highlights that mature devotion arises from emotional regulation and centered attention: when attachment, fear and anger quiet, attention stabilizes and devotion deepens. In modern life, cultivating equanimity (through practices like mindfulness, cognitive reframing, and emotional intelligence) allows one to orient toward meaningful goals without being driven by reactivity. Surrender here is not passivity but intentional prioritization—relinquishing short-term impulses and anxieties to commit to a larger ethical or spiritual aim, thereby reducing inner turmoil and enhancing purposeful action.

verses.sanskrit: किं कर्म किमकर्मेति कवयो पण्डितं म्हणन्ति। अतयवश्यमवश्यमिति तु काछन न व्यतीतिः॥
verses.transliteration: Kiṃ karma kim-akarmeti kavayaḥ paṇḍitaṃ manyante; ataḥ avasyam avasyam iti tu kaccit na vyatītiḥ.
verses.translation: ‘What is action, what is inaction,’ the learned among sages consider; beyond that, they say ‘certainly there is compulsion and non-compulsion,’ but truly one cannot categorically go beyond all such distinctions.
verses.context: This verse raises the ethical-philosophical dilemma about what counts as action and inaction. In the ongoing discourse, Krishna acknowledges the subtlety of moral categories: reflective sages debate the boundaries between action, inaction and forbidden action, and the practical limits of such distinctions. The verse frames the problem that precedes Krishna’s exposition on the nature of action performed with or without attachment, and it prepares Arjuna to understand the finer points of duty and renunciation.
verses.explanation: Not all choices are obvious. Discernment matters.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically, the question about action versus inaction probes accountability and intentionality: are we responsible for outcomes of acts beyond conscious intention? Modern application: in complex systems (workplaces, relationships) actions have cascading effects; thus ethical discernment must account for consequences, intent and constraints. Cognitive biases and situational pressures can blur responsibility. Practically, cultivate reflective pause, seek counsel, and clarify values to distinguish deliberate choices from coerced or habitual behaviors—reducing regret and improving moral clarity in ambiguous situations.

verses.sanskrit: कर्मणो ह्यपि बोद्धव्यं बोद्धव्यं च विकर्मणः। अकर्मणश्च बोद्धव्यं गहना कर्मणः क्रमः॥
verses.transliteration: Karmaṇo hy api boddhavyaṃ boddhavyaṃ ca vikarmaṇaḥ; akarmaṇaś ca boddhavyaṃ gahanā karmaṇaḥ kramaḥ.
verses.translation: Action indeed must be known; the wrong action must be known; the non-action also must be known — the sequence of action is profound and subtle.
verses.context: Following the question about action and inaction, Krishna explains that one must understand the nature of action (karma), wrong action (vikarma), and non-action (akarma). He emphasizes that the proper order and discrimination among these is deep and not obvious. This sets up the instruction on acting without attachment and acting in accordance with svadharma (one’s own duty), indicating that moral agency depends on nuanced understanding rather than simplistic rules.
verses.explanation: Not all actions are simple to judge.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse points to psychological sophistication: moral life requires discernment of what constitutes rightful action, wrongful action, and abstention. Modern life complicates these categories through interdependence and moral pluralism. Practically, cultivate ethical literacy—study consequences, context and motives—while developing inner steadiness to act from principle rather than impulse. Decision frameworks (values clarification, stakeholder analysis) and reflective practices (journaling, supervision) help navigate ‘gahanā karmaṇaḥ kramaḥ’—the complex sequence of actions—reducing moral confusion and enabling responsible, proportionate responses.

verses.sanskrit:
नैव किंचित् करोमि इति युक्तः कृत्स्नकर्मकृत् ।
अकर्मणि च कर्माणि सङ्गविवृत्ते स्थितः ॥
verses.transliteration: naiva kiñcit karomi iti yuktaḥ kṛtsna-karma-kṛt | akarmaṇi ca karmāṇi saṅga-vivṛtte sthitaḥ ||
verses.translation: na eva — not indeed; kiñcit — anything; karomi — I do (say); iti — thus; yuktaḥ — established/yoked; kṛtsna — entire/complete; karma — of actions; kṛt — doer; akarmaṇi — in non-action; ca — and; karmāṇi — actions; saṅga — attachment; vivṛtte — having been separated/dissolved; sthitaḥ — situated/standing. (Literal:) ‘‘Not ‘I do anything,’ (says) the one established, the doer of all actions; in non-action also (he) performs actions, being established when attachment is severed.’
verses.context: In Book Five (Karma-yoga), Krishna answers Arjuna's puzzlement about how one can be active in the world yet remain unattached. This verse follows the explanation that true renunciation is inner — renunciation of desire/attachment — not mere outward cessation of work. Krishna is distinguishing the realized person who, while appearing to act or not-act, has uprooted the sense of personal doership. The teaching situates agency as a conditioned perception that can be overturned by yogic clarity, thereby reconciling ethical action with spiritual freedom.
