verses.detailed_explanation: This verse addresses the psychological split between identity and action: the realized person no longer confuses the temporary controller-self with the doer. Practically, it cultivates a witness stance—observing impulses and behaviors without overidentifying—reducing reactivity and shame. In modern life this enables professionals and caregivers to perform duties effectively while preventing burnout: actions are done responsibly, but self-worth is decoupled from outcomes. The practice builds resilience by replacing ego-based ownership with sober, compassionate responsibility.

verses.sanskrit:
ब्रह्मण्याधाय कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा करोति यः ।
लिप्यते न स पापेभ्यः मोहितोऽप्रमादवर्जितः ॥
verses.transliteration: brahmaṇy ādhāya karmāṇi saṅgaṁ tyaktvā karoti yaḥ | lipyate na sa pāpebhyaḥ mohito 'pramāda-varjitaḥ ||
verses.translation: brahmaṇi — in (or to) Brahman; ādhāya — having placed; karmāṇi — actions; saṅgam — attachment; tyaktvā — having abandoned; karoti — does; yaḥ — he who; lipyate — is not tainted/stained; na — not; saḥ — he; pāpebhyaḥ — by sins; mohitaḥ — deluded/confused; apramāda-varjitaḥ — free from negligence/without heedlessness. (Literal:) ‘‘He who, placing actions in Brahman and having abandoned attachment, does (them), is not tainted by sins; (he is) not deluded and free from negligence.’
verses.context: This teaching continues the theme of selfless action. Krishna tells Arjuna that when a person offers their work into the dimension of the divine (Brahman) and lets go of clinging to results, the moral stain (karma-as-pāpa) does not bind them. The verse clarifies how interior orientation — offering and non-attachment — transforms ordinary actions into liberating practice. It reinforces that liberation is not escape from action but a change in relationship to action: responsibility without egoistic grasping.
verses.explanation: Detachment protects inner balance without reducing effort.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically, this verse teaches cognitive re-appraisal: reframing tasks as service to a larger value reduces personal threat and moral anxiety. By symbolically 'placing' work into a broader purpose, one lessens performance-driven self-worth and the fear of blame. For modern workers this reduces burnout and defensiveness: outcomes matter but do not define the self. Practically, it encourages mindful intention-setting, steady attention, and accountability without compulsive identification — a healthier motivational structure for sustained engagement.

verses.sanskrit:
युक्तः कर्मफलत्यक्त्वा शारीरं यत्र निहीयते ।
ध्यानयोगिनि स्थिरसंकल्पे प्रकृत्यैव न संशयः ॥
verses.transliteration: yuktaḥ karma-phala-tyaktvā śārīraṁ yatra nihīyate | dhyāna-yogini sthira-saṅkalpe prakṛty eva na saṁśayaḥ ||
verses.translation: yuktaḥ — established/attuned; karma-phala — the fruit of action; tyaktvā — having renounced; śārīram — the body; yatra — where; nihīyate — is placed/abandoned; dhyāna-yogini — in the one established in meditation/yoga; sthira-saṅkalpe — with firm resolution; prakṛtyā — by nature; eva — indeed; na — not; saṁśayaḥ — doubt. (Literal:) ‘‘The one established (in yoga), having renounced the fruit of action, where the body is set aside; in the meditator with firm resolve, by nature indeed there is no doubt.’
verses.context: This verse situates the yogī who has relinquished attachment to results and whose body is treated as an instrument rather than the self. It follows Krishna's argument that when the inner will is steady and oriented to meditation, actions no longer create binding consequences in the same way. The verse contrasts a settled inner disposition (sthirā saṅkalpa) with ordinary, conflicted action. It points to the transformative role of inner stability in dissolving the karmic loop.
verses.detailed_explanation: Here the Gītā speaks to the calming of internal conflict through steady intention and reduced outcome-dependence. Psychologically, renouncing fruits is akin to detaching self-worth from success metrics; treating the body as instrument reduces somatic anxiety about results. Modern application: teams and individuals benefit when goals are pursued with disciplined intention rather than fear-driven clinging—improving creativity, reducing stress responses, and enabling ethical decision-making under pressure.

verses.sanskrit:
विद्या-विनय-सम्पन्ने ब्राह्मणे गवि हस्तिनि ।
शूद्राः अपि यान्ति पण्डिताः सम-दर्शिनः ॥
verses.transliteration: vidyā-vinaya-sampanne brāhmaṇe gavi hastini | śūdrāṇām api yānti pañḍitāḥ sama-darśinaḥ ||
verses.translation: vidyā — learning/knowledge; vinaya — humility/modesty; sampanne — endowed; brāhmaṇe — in a brahmana/best person; gavi — in a cow; hastini — in an elephant; śūdrāṇām — among śūdras (laborers); api — even; yānti — go/reach; pañḍitāḥ — the wise; sama-darśinaḥ — seeing equally. (Literal:) ‘‘The wise, seeing with equal vision, regard a learned humble person, a cow, an elephant, even a śūdra, as alike; the learned attain (that state).’’
verses.context: This verse emphasizes the equanimity that true knowledge and humility produce. Krishna points out that a person endowed with learning and humility sees all beings without hierarchical prejudice. In the context of the Gītā's social and spiritual teaching, this is a corrective to caste-based pride: wisdom dissolves superficial distinctions and fosters universal respect. It follows an ethical arc in the chapter showing how inner transformation reshapes social perception and conduct.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically the verse describes cognitive empathy born of humility: knowledgeable humility reduces social comparison and rigid labeling. When one recognizes shared sentience and impairment of egoistic superiority, prejudice softens. Modern implications include promoting inclusive leadership and anti-bias training: cultivating curiosity and modesty undermines stereotyping, enabling fairer decisions and deeper connection. Practically, practices that combine learning with reflective humility (journaling, feedback, mentoring) foster the same equal-seeing mindset described here.

verses.sanskrit:
यै हि संस्पर्शजा भोगा दुःखयोनय एव ते ।
आद्यन्तवन्तः कौन्तेय न तेषु रमते बुधः ॥
verses.transliteration:
Ye hi saṃsparśajā bhogā duḥkha-yonaya eva te |
ādyanta-vantaḥ kaunteya na teṣu ramate budhaḥ ||
verses.translation: Those indeed pleasures born of contact — generators/wombs of sorrow they are; having a beginning and an end, O son of Kunti, the wise do not delight in them.
verses.context: Spoken by Krishna in the context of Chapter 5 (Karma-yoga / Renunciation), this verse follows a teaching on the distinction between fleeting sensory pleasures and enduring wisdom. Krishna addresses Arjuna (Kaunteya), warning that sensual enjoyments that arise from contact with the senses lead to suffering. The passage contrasts the transient nature of sense-based gratification with the steady state of the wise who renounce attachment, outlining ethical practice for one pursuing liberation through disciplined action and discrimination.
verses.explanation: Short-term pleasure often creates long-term cost.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically, this verse highlights how stimulus-driven rewards condition behavior toward repeated seeking despite net harm. Modern neuroscience shows that dopamine-linked cue-reward cycles make contact-born pleasures compelling yet unsatisfying. For practical application, cultivate meta-awareness: notice the attraction, acknowledge impermanence, and choose actions aligned with longer-term values. Cognitive strategies — delay, substitution, and reframing — help break habitual pursuit. Over time, reducing reactivity to sensory triggers fosters emotional stability, clearer priorities, and reduced compulsivity, enabling wiser choices consistent with long-term wellbeing.

verses.sanskrit:
शक्नोतीहैव यः सोढुं कामान्
क्लेशोपशमाय समः स बुद्धिमान् ।
verses.transliteration:
Śaknotīhaiva yaḥ soḍhuṃ kāmān
kleśopaśamāya samaḥ sa buddhimān |
verses.translation: He who here is indeed able to endure (soḍhuṃ) the desires for calming of distress, remaining even-minded — he is wise.
verses.context: This verse continues the ethical-psychological instruction in Chapter 5 on self-control and equanimity. Krishna speaks to Arjuna about the capacity required to withstand and regulate desire-driven impulses (kāma) and the mental disturbances they cause (kleśa). The emphasis is on an inner steadiness (samatvam) that allows one to face cravings without being driven by them; such endurance and balance are marks of wisdom and maturity within the broader discourse on action, renunciation, and the path to liberation.
verses.detailed_explanation: This shloka underscores resilience: the ability to tolerate internal urges without surrendering to them. Psychologically, it points to distress tolerance and impulse regulation — core skills in therapies like DBT. In modern life, practicing brief pauses, labeling cravings, and using grounding techniques allow ‘enduring’ rather than capitulating to impulses. Over time, this enhances self-efficacy and reduces regret-driven behaviors. Cultivating acceptance of discomfort while maintaining value-directed action leads to wiser decisions and sustained mental health.

verses.sanskrit:
लभन्ते ब्रह्मनिर्वाणं तत्त्ववित् संततं परिमार्जितं
शान्तिम् आत्मविनिगृहीत्वा नान्यः पन्था विद्यते ॥
verses.transliteration:
Labhante brahma-nirvāṇaṃ tattva-vit santataṃ parimārjitaṃ
śāntim ātma-vinigṛhītvā nānyaḥ panthā vidyate ||
verses.translation: Those who know the truth attain Brahman-nirvāṇa — continually purified, having taken hold of (vinigṛhītvā) inner peace; there is no other path.
verses.context: Situated in Krishna's exposition on the fruits of disciplined action and knowledge in Chapter 5, this verse declares that the true knower (tattva-vit) attains Brahman and final release (nirvāṇa). The emphasis is on continual purification and the internal appropriation of peace; liberation is presented as the result of right understanding and steady inner practice. The verse affirms the primacy of self-realization over transient means and situates liberation as the culmination of the yoga of knowledge and action.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse points to the transformative endpoint of disciplined inner work: a stable peace anchored in understanding rather than external conditions. Psychologically, it mirrors the shift from reactive patterns to integrated self-regulation — when one discerns transient impulses from enduring values, inner turbulence subsides. Modern practice can include mindfulness, reflective inquiry, and ethical action to purify habits and integrate insights. Over time, such integration fosters resilience, reduces existential anxiety, and cultivates a sense of profound sufficiency that lessens craving for external validation.

verses.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच
अनाश्रितः कर्मफलं कार्यं कर्म करोति यः
स सङ्ख्ययै न प्रवर्तते॥
verses.transliteration:
Śrī-bhagavān uvāca
Anāśritaḥ karma-phalaṃ kāryaṃ karma karoti yaḥ
sa saṅkhyai na pravartate ||
verses.translation: The Blessed Lord said: He who performs action whose fruit is not relied upon (anāśritaḥ karma-phalam) — that action should be done; he who acts thus does not proceed in the way of the Saṅkhya (i.e., mere philosophical renunciation).
verses.context: Beginning of Chapter 6 (Dhyāna-yoga / The Yoga of Meditation), Krishna responds to Arjuna’s question about renunciation and the practice of yoga. Here Krishna distinguishes between mere philosophical renunciation (Saṅkhya) and active selfless performance of duty (Karma without attachment). He teaches that action performed without attachment to results is superior to passive renunciation; this sets the stage for instructions on meditation as an extension of disciplined, detached action.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse reframes work as a means of practice rather than a source of identity or reward. Psychologically, detaching self-worth from outcomes reduces performance anxiety and the chronic stress that leads to burnout. By focusing on process and intention, individuals can maintain motivation while avoiding obsessive outcome-dependence. Practical steps include clarifying values, setting process-based goals, and practicing acceptance of results. Over time, this cultivates intrinsic motivation, resilience in setbacks, and a healthier relationship with achievement.

verses.sanskrit:
सुखदुःखे समे कृत्वा लाभालाभौ जयाजयौ ।
ततो युद्धाय युज्यस्व योगाय च कौशलं कुरु ॥
verses.transliteration:
sukha-duḥkhe same kṛtvā lābhālābhau jayājayau |
tato yuddhāya yujyasva yogāya ca kauśalaṁ kuru ||
verses.translation: sukha-duḥkhe — in pleasure and in pain; same kṛtvā — having made equal; lābha-ālābhau — gain and loss; jaya-ajayau — victory and defeat; tato — therefore; yuddhāya — for battle (for the task); yujyasva — engage yourself; yogāya ca — also for yoga; kauśalam — skill; kuru — do/make. (Literal: Having made pleasure and pain, gain and loss, victory and defeat equal, therefore engage for the battle; make skill for yoga.)
verses.context: Arjuna is being instructed in Chapter 6 (Dhyāna-yoga) on the inner temperament required for both spiritual practice and outer duty. Here Krishna emphasizes inner equipoise toward opposites — pleasure/pain, gain/loss, victory/defeat — and links that inner steadiness to effective action. The setting: after describing methods of meditation and self-control, Krishna reminds Arjuna that such an even-minded outlook is not only for contemplatives but also equips one to act in the world with skillful detachment. This teaching bridges renunciation and right action.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse teaches practical equanimity: by regarding pleasure and pain, gains and losses, successes and failures as equal, one stabilizes the mind. Psychologically, it reduces reactive swings driven by craving and aversion; it creates a steady baseline from which choices arise from values rather than impulse. In modern life this translates into stress-resilience — making decisions without being hijacked by short-term rewards or setbacks. In performance contexts (work, relationships) it encourages focus on process and skill, not outcomes, reducing anxiety and improving consistent effectiveness.

verses.sanskrit:
योगी युज्येत सततं आत्मानं रहसी स्थितः ।
एकाकी यतचित्तात्मा नियतात्मा मत्परः ॥
verses.transliteration:
yogī yujyeta satataṁ ātmānaṁ rahasī sthitaḥ |
eka-kī yatacittātmā niyata-ātmā mat-paraḥ ||
verses.translation: yogī — a yogi; yujyeta — should train; satatam — constantly; ātmānam — himself; rahasi — in secret/retreat; sthitaḥ — placed/established. ekākī — solitary; yatacitta-ātmā — one whose mind is controlled/with steady mind; niyata-ātmā — disciplined in self; mat-paraḥ — devoted to Me. (Literal: A yogi should constantly train himself, established in seclusion; solitary, whose mind is disciplined, self-regulated, devoted to Me.)
verses.context: Within the Dhyāna-yoga chapter, Krishna advises Arjuna on how a sincere practitioner should conduct their training. After describing posture and breath control, Krishna prescribes an attitude and setting: steady, continuous practice, often in disciplined seclusion, with an inwardly governed mind. This verse situates the aspirant who seeks deep meditation as one who cultivates constancy, discipline, and devotion. It speaks both to recluse-bound practice and to the inner solitude of focused attention even amid life’s duties — the inner orientation matters more than external withdrawal.
verses.detailed_explanation: The verse emphasizes disciplined, sustained practice in a quiet interior space. Psychologically this recognizes that habit formation and deep attention require constancy and periods of reduced distraction. Modern application: set regular times for focused work or meditation; cultivate brief, private practices (even at home) to strengthen attention. The solitary attitude is not isolation but concentrated focus; devotion (mat‑para) supplies motivational steadiness. This reduces reactivity and builds mental clarity, enabling more resilient, purposeful engagement with daily challenges.

verses.sanskrit:
नात्यश्नतस्तु योगोऽस्ति न चैकान्तमनश्नत् ।
न चातिस्वप्नशीलस्य जाग्रतो नैव चार्जुन ॥
verses.transliteration:
nātya-śnataḥ tu yogo 'sti na ca ekāntamanśnataḥ |
na cāti-svapna-śīlasya jāgrato naiva cārjuna ||
verses.translation: na — not; aty-aśnataḥ — one who eats excessively; tu — but; yogo asti — there is yoga; na ca — nor; ekānta-man-aśnataḥ — one who only abstains from eating entirely (excessive fasting); na ca ati-svapna-śīlasya — nor for one whose habit is too much sleep; jāgrataḥ — for one who is always awake; na eva — certainly not; ca arjuna — O Arjuna. (Literal: Yoga is not for the one who eats too much, nor for the one who eats too little exclusively; nor for one given to excessive sleep or constant waking.)
verses.context: Krishna here lays down rules of moderation in the Dhyāna-yoga teachings. After instructing on posture and concentration, he cautions against extremes in bodily regimen: neither overeating nor severe fasting, neither excessive sleep nor constant sleeplessness. This is practical advice for meditators and activists alike: extremes disturb bodily and mental equilibrium and impede sustained practice. In the narrative, Krishna addresses Arjuna’s confusion about discipline, steering him toward the Middle Way — a balanced regimen that supports steady meditation and effective action.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse underscores balance in basic routines as foundational for mental health. Psychologically, extremes in eating and sleep dysregulate mood, cognition, and attention, undermining any contemplative or professional effort. Modern application: prioritize consistent sleep schedules and moderate, regular meals to stabilize energy and focus. Balanced self-care creates conditions for sustained concentration and emotional regulation, preventing burnout. The teaching is a pragmatic reminder that spiritual or performance goals depend on bodily rhythms; respect of these rhythms enhances resilience and clarity.

verses.sanskrit:
युक्ताहारविहारस्य युक्तचेष्टस्य कर्मसु ।
युक्तस्वप्नावबोधस्य योगो भवति दुःखहा ॥
verses.transliteration:
yukta-āhāra-vihārasya yukta-ceṣṭasya karmasu |
yukta-svapna-avabodhasya yogo bhavati duḥkhahā ||
verses.translation: yukta — regulated/moderate; āhāra-vihārasya — in eating and recreation; yukta-ceṣṭasya — in activities when they are moderate; karmasu — in actions; yukta-svapna-avabodhasya — in sleeping and waking regulated; yogo — yoga; bhavati — becomes; duḥkha-hā — destroyer of sorrow. (Literal: For one moderate in food and recreation, moderate in deeds, regulated in sleep and waking, yoga becomes the destroyer of suffering.)
verses.context: Following the warning against extremes, Krishna prescribes a balanced lifestyle as the basis for successful yoga. This verse summarizes the regimen: moderation in food and recreation, measured action, and disciplined sleep–wake cycles produce a condition where yoga (union/stillness of mind) can dispel suffering. In the broader narrative Krishna presents this as actionable wisdom: ethical and bodily moderation prepare the mind for concentration, making both inner transformation and effective outer service possible.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse connects lifestyle habits to psychological well‑being: moderation in diet, activity, and sleep creates steadiness, allowing mental training to reduce suffering. Psychologically, consistent routines reduce decision fatigue and stabilize mood, enabling deeper focus and fewer impulsive reactions. In modern terms: cultivate regular meals, measured leisure, disciplined work habits, and consistent sleep to support mental health practices like mindfulness or focused work. Over time these habits decrease anxiety, improve resilience, and make transformative practices more effective and sustainable.

verses.sanskrit: तं विद्धि प्रणिपातेन परिप्रश्नेन सेवया । उपदेक्ष्यन्ति ते ज्ञानं ज्ञानिनः तत्त्वदर्शिनः ॥
verses.transliteration: Taṃ viddhi praṇipātena paripraśnena sevayā | upadekṣyanti te jñānaṃ jñāninaḥ tattva-darśinaḥ ||
verses.translation: That (taṃ) know (viddhi) — by humble prostration (praṇipātena), by thorough questioning (paripraśnena), by service (sevayā). Will teach (upadekṣyanti) to you (te) the knowledge (jñānam) those-knowers (jñāninaḥ) who-are-seers-of-truth (tattva-darśinaḥ).
verses.context: In the dialog of Dhyāna-yoga (chapter 6), Krishna instructs Arjuna that spiritual knowledge and the means to steady the mind are transmitted not by arrogance but by humility and disciplined inquiry. Here Krishna describes the traditional guru–śiṣya process: approach a realized teacher with reverence (praṇipāta), ask sincere questions (paripraśna) and render service (sevā). Philosophically this locates realization in a living lineage and disciplined practice rather than mere intellectual study.
verses.explanation: Freedom is not absence of pain, but absence of bondage.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse points to humility, inquiry and dedicated practice as the psychological gateway to transformation. Modern therapy parallels this: a client’s humble openness, careful questioning, and sustained practice (homework) allow the therapist’s insights to become integrated. Approaching a practice or mentor with receptivity reduces ego-defensiveness, enables corrective emotional experiences, and accelerates neuroplastic change. It emphasizes relational learning—wisdom transmitted through trust, disciplined engagement, and experiential guidance rather than mere information.

verses.sanskrit: शैनैः शैनैः पुनरागमाध्य बुद्ध्या धृत्या यतते ।
verses.transliteration: Śainaiḥ śainaiḥ punar āgamād buddhyā dhṛtyā yatate ||
verses.translation: Slowly, slowly (śainaiḥ śainaiḥ), from repeated return/relapse (punar āgamāt), by intelligence/discernment (buddhyā) and by steadfastness/fortitude (dhṛtyā) one strives/endeavors (yatate).
verses.context: Within Krishna’s teaching on meditation and mental discipline, this verse counsels patience. The mind returns to old patterns; progress in taming it is gradual. Situated after instructions on practice and control, the teaching reassures the seeker that steady effort — informed by discrimination and sustained will — effects change. Philosophically it underscores gradual habituation (samskāra transformation) rather than instantaneous eradication of mental tendencies.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically this verse affirms that habit-change is incremental. Neural and behavioral shifts occur through repeated small acts: noticing, redirecting attention, and persistent practice. Using discernment (buddhi) and steady resolve (dhṛti) prevents discouragement after relapses. In contemporary terms, it mirrors staged-change models and ‘tiny habits’ strategies: celebrate small wins, expect setbacks, and return without self-condemnation. Over time, repetition weakens old triggers and builds new automatic responses, yielding durable inner stability.

verses.sanskrit: यतो यतो निश्चरति मनश्चञ्चलमस्थिरम् । ततस्ततो नियम्यैतदात्मन्येव वासांसि संयम्य च ॥
verses.transliteration: Yato yato niścarati manaś cañchalaṃ asthiram | tatastato niyamya etad ātmany eva vāsāṃsi saṃyamya ca ||
verses.translation: Whenever (yato yato) wanders (niścarati) the mind (manaḥ), restless (cañchalaṃ) and unstable (asthiram), then (tataḥ) restraining it (niyamya) bring this (etad) back into the Self alone (ātmani eva), having controlled (saṃyamya) the (impelling) tendencies/senses (vāsāṃsi) as well (ca).
verses.context: Following methods to steady the mind, Krishna gives a practical instruction for the meditator: whenever the mind strays, gently but firmly bring it back and control the sense-desires. This is situated in the larger philosophical framework that the Self (ātman) is the stable ground and the mind must be repeatedly reoriented to it. Krishna advocates persistent, nonviolent re-direction rather than punishment of the mind.
verses.explanation: Control is gentle redirection, not force.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse models a compassionate approach to attention training: notice wandering without harsh judgment, then redirect. It aligns with mindfulness-based practices and cognitive therapies that use metacognitive awareness to decouple identification from thought. Repeated nonreactive returns retrain attentional networks and reduce rumination. Psychologically, it strengthens the capacity for self-regulation and interrupts automatic reactivity, permitting clearer choice. Over time this improves emotional resilience and reduces anxiety driven by uncontrolled mental loops.

verses.sanskrit: सर्वभूतस्थमात्मानं सर्वभूतानि चात्मनि । ईक्षते योगयुक्तात्मा सर्वत्र समदर्शिनः ॥
verses.transliteration: Sarva-bhūta-stham ātmānaṃ sarva-bhūtāni ca ātmani | īkṣate yoga-yukta-ātmā sarvatra sama-darśinaḥ ||
verses.translation: The Self (ātman) dwelling in all beings (sarva-bhūta-stham), and all beings (sarva-bhūtāni) in the Self (ca ātmani), sees (īkṣate) the yogi united with yoga (yoga-yukta-ātmā) as one who sees alike everywhere (sarvatra sama-darśinaḥ).
verses.context: In the course of instructing how a perfected yogi perceives reality, Krishna describes the non-dual vision of an advanced practitioner. This comes after advice on meditation and detachment: when the mind is stilled, perception shifts from separative seeing to recognizing the same Self pervading all beings. Philosophically this affirms the upanishadic insight of inner unity and the yogic ethic of impartiality.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse encourages perceiving others as expressions of the same inner self, which fosters empathy, reduces bias, and mitigates isolation. Psychologically, cultivating a sense of common humanity counters social anxiety and promotes prosocial behavior. Practically, techniques such as perspective-taking, loving-kindness meditation, and values-based cognition nurture this stance. Recognizing inner unity does not erase differences but reframes them, allowing engagement from a calmer, less reactive place and improving interpersonal relationships and community well‑being.

verses.sanskrit:
आरुरुक्षोर्मुनैर्गृह्यते योगोऽभ्यासेन प्रतिष्ठितः ।
यदात्मनि स्थिरं मनः स योगी स्याद् स्थितचेतसः ॥
verses.transliteration: Ārurukṣor munair gṛhyate yogo'bhyāsena pratiṣṭhitaḥ | yad ātmani sthiraṁ manaḥ sa yogī syād sthitachetasaḥ ||
verses.translation: Ārurukṣoḥ — by the sage who endures hardships; munaiḥ — by sages; gṛhyate — is taken/obtained; yogaḥ — the state of yoga; abhyāsena — through practice; pratiṣṭhitaḥ — established; yat — that which; ātmani — in the self; sthiram — steady/firm; manaḥ — the mind; saḥ — that one; yogī — a yogin; syāt — becomes; sthita-cetasaḥ — having a steady (fixed) consciousness.
verses.context: Here Krishna emphasizes that yoga is not merely a theoretical state but the fruit of sustained practice under austere, disciplined living. In the narrative of the Gita, this appears as part of Krishna’s guidance to Arjuna on disciplined inner work. Philosophically, it links tapas (austerity and disciplined effort) and sādhanā (spiritual practice) to arriving at a steady mind — the essential condition for effective meditation and right action. It counters the idea that revelation or grace replaces practical effort.
verses.explanation: Stillness matures through engagement, not avoidance.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse stresses that resilience and disciplined practice forge inner steadiness. Psychologically, repeated disciplined acts (habituation) rewire attention and emotional reactivity, producing a stable mind. In modern terms: regular routines, focused practice (meditation, therapy homework), and tolerating discomfort grow psychological flexibility. For someone struggling with distraction or inconsistency, the takeaway is pragmatic: cultivate small, sustained practices rather than wait for sudden insight. Over time this creates a reliable baseline of equanimity, enabling clearer choice and less reactivity in daily life.

verses.sanskrit:
उद्धरेदात्मनात्मानं नात्मानमवसादयेत् ।
आत्मैव ह्यात्मनो बन्धुरात्मैव रिपुरात्मनः ॥
verses.transliteration: Uddhared ātmanātmānaṁ nātmānam avasādayet | ātmaiva hy ātmano bandhur ātmaiva ripur ātmanaḥ ||
verses.translation: Uddharet — should uplift; ātmanā — by (one's) own self; ātmānam — oneself; na — not; ātmānam — oneself; avasādayet — let one cause to decline; ātmaiva — the self indeed; hi — certainly; ātmano — of the self; bandhuḥ — is a friend; ātmaiva — the self indeed; ripuḥ — is an enemy; ātmanaḥ — of the self.
verses.context: In the discourse on self-discipline, Krishna instructs Arjuna that deliverance or ruin depend upon one’s own attitude and effort. Narratively, this follows the teaching on steady practice and control of the mind. Philosophically, it asserts self-agency: liberation (mokṣa) and bondage (baddha) both arise from the inner orientation of the individual. It shifts responsibility inward, emphasizing ethical self-regulation over external blaming, and situates spiritual progress as an outcome of personal effort guided by right knowledge.
verses.explanation: Recovery begins internally. Support helps, but effort starts within.
verses.detailed_explanation: The verse addresses the fundamental psychological principle of agency: we are architects of our uplift or decline. Cognitively, it points to self-efficacy—beliefs about one’s ability to effect change. Practically, this encourages taking responsibility for small, consistent actions (sleep, nutrition, practice) that shape mood and capability. For therapy or coaching, it underlines empowering clients to initiate self-directed steps rather than adopting helplessness. Emotionally, it invites compassionate but firm self-guidance: be your own friend through steady encouragement and disciplined choices to counter self-sabotage.

verses.sanskrit:
बन्धुरात्मात्मनस्तस्य येनात्मानं जितःस्थितः ।
अनात्मनस्तु शत्रुत्वे कार्यः स आत्मैव रिपुः ॥
verses.transliteration: Bandhur ātmātmanas tasya yena ātmanam jitaḥ sthitaḥ | anātmanas tu śatrutve kāryaḥ sa ātmāiva ripuḥ ||
verses.translation: Bandhuḥ — (a) friend; ātmātmanas — of the self by the self; tasya — for him; yena — by whom; ātmanam — the self; jitaḥ — conquered; sthitaḥ — established/standing; an-ātmanas — of the one not self-controlled; tu — but; śatrutve — in enmity/hostility; kāryaḥ — is to be done/considered; saḥ — that one; ātmā eva — indeed the self; ripuḥ — is an enemy.
verses.context: Following the injunction to uplift oneself, the Gita clarifies that for a person who has mastered the self the self is a friend; conversely for one who has not mastered desires and impulses, the self acts as an enemy. This teaching occurs amid Krishna’s broader counsel on self-mastery, discipline, and the inner battlefield. Philosophically it delineates intra-psychic conflict—how uncontrolled drives turn the agent against its own flourishing—and stresses moral psychology as central to spiritual liberation.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically, this verse maps onto self-regulation: when impulses are integrated, the self supports its goals; when unchecked, it undermines them. Modern applications include forming habits, impulse-control strategies, and cognitive restructuring to align short-term drives with long-term values. For someone facing self-sabotage (procrastination, addiction), the guidance is to cultivate practices that domesticate impulses—mindfulness, commitment devices, and gradual exposure—so that the ‘inner enemy’ is transformed into an ally for sustained well‑being.

verses.sanskrit:
ज्‍ञानेन तृप्तः आत्मा कृत्स्नकर्मकृत् निबध्यते ।
युक्तबुद्धिर्मुक्तोऽभ्येति ब्रह्मभूयोऽभिसमयः ॥
verses.transliteration: Jñānena tṛptaḥ ātmā kṛtsna‑karma‑kṛt na nibadhyate | yuktabuddhir mukto 'bhyeti brahma‑bhūyo 'bhisamayaḥ ||
verses.translation: Jñānena — by knowledge; tṛptaḥ — satisfied; ātmā — the self; kṛtsna‑karma‑kṛt — even performing all actions; na — not; nibadhyate — is bound; yuktabuddhiḥ — whose intellect is steady/regulated; muktaḥ — freed; abhyeti — goes forth/attains; brahma‑bhūyaḥ — to being Brahman; abhisamayaḥ — the attainment/meeting.
verses.context: Krishna explains the state of the realized person: even while engaged in action, if the self is satisfied with knowledge and has a disciplined intellect, one is not bound and proceeds toward union with Brahman. Within the Gita’s narrative, this reinforces the synthesis of action (karma) and wisdom (jñāna) — practice and insight together free the practitioner. Philosophically it affirms that right understanding transforms activity from bondage into the path of liberation.
verses.explanation: Knowledge integrated with experience steadies identity.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse highlights integration: mature knowledge turns action into non-binding activity. Psychologically, it parallels achieving reflective awareness where behavior flows from values rather than compulsions. In modern practice, combining cognitive insight (therapy, education) with embodied routines (mindfulness, ethical action) reduces guilt and rumination, enabling purposeful engagement. For professionals, it suggests aligning work with clarified values; for individuals, it means that understanding one’s motives transforms obligations into meaningful expressions, freeing one from reactive entanglement and fostering inner peace.

verses.sanskrit: आत्मौपमेयेन सर्वत्र समं पश्यति योऽर्जुन । सुखं वा यदि वा दुःखं स च न विनश्यति ॥
verses.transliteration: ātmaupamayena sarvatra samaṁ paśyati yo 'rjuna | sukhaṁ vā yadi vā duḥkhaṁ sa ca na vinaśyati ||
verses.translation: ātmaupamayena — by comparison/analogy with the Self; sarvatra — everywhere; samaṁ paśyati — (he) sees as equal; yo 'rjuna — who, O Arjuna; sukhaṁ vā yadi vā duḥkhaṁ — pleasure or if (also) pain; sa ca na vinaśyati — he also does not perish/deteriorate.
verses.context: Chapter 6 (Dhyāna-yoga) develops the practice of meditation and inner discipline. Here Krishna answers Arjuna’s practical concern about steadiness and compassion arising from inner realization. Within the flow of instructions on controlling the mind and attaining samādhi, Krishna describes the fruit of realizing the Self: an all-pervading equanimity that perceives others through the lens of the Self. The verse situates ethical behavior (compassion, non-harm) in metaphysical insight: when one sees the same Self in all, pleasure and pain no longer disturb one’s equipoise.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse locates compassion in realized identity: when a practitioner recognizes the same Self everywhere, reactive swings to pleasure or pain diminish. Psychologically, it describes a shift from self-centered valuation to perspective-taking grounded in core identity, which reduces threat‑driven reactivity and moral partiality. In modern terms, cultivating practices that reveal continuity with others — e.g., reflective meditation, perspective exercises, and compassion training — can produce more stable emotional regulation, less impulsive reactivity, and ethical choices that endure under stress.

verses.sanskrit: असंशयं महाबाहो मनो दुर्निग्रहं चलम् । अभ्यासेन तु कौन्तेय वैराग्येण च गृह्यते ॥
verses.transliteration: asaṁśayaṁ mahā-bāho mano durnigrahaṁ calam | abhyāsena tu kaunteya vairāgyeṇa ca gṛhyate ||
verses.translation: asaṁśayam — without doubt; mahā-bāho — O mighty-armed; manaḥ — the mind; durnigrahaṁ — difficult to restrain/hold; calam — restless; abhyāsena — by practice; tu — indeed/but; kaunteya — O son of Kunti; vairāgyeṇa — by dispassion/detachment; ca — and; gṛhyate — is grasped/restrained.
verses.context: In the same chapter on meditation, Arjuna expresses worry about the mind’s restlessness and Krishna answers candidly. Rather than promise instantaneous mastery, Krishna names the mind’s nature as fickle and confirms a pragmatic remedy: disciplined practice (abhyāsa) coupled with detachment (vairāgya). The teaching balances acknowledgement of human difficulty with a disciplined path, situating ethical and meditative progress as gradual, requiring repeated effort and tempering of desire, not instantaneous eradication of mental turbulence.
verses.explanation: Krishna validates the struggle instead of dismissing it. Mastery of the mind is not instant; it is gradual. Progress comes through patience and repeated practice, not self-criticism.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically, this verse normalizes the persistence of distractible, restless thought and prescribes two complementary interventions: repeated training and reduced attachment. Practice builds new neural habits and self-regulatory capacity; detachment lowers the motivational charge that fuels reactivity. In contemporary terms, this maps to consistent mindfulness or behavioral practice plus cognitive reframing to reduce craving-driven responses. Together they strengthen attention, reduce rumination, and foster sustainable change. The remedy is iterative: gradual gains accumulate through disciplined repetition and diminished emotional investment in transient incentives.

verses.sanskrit: मनुष्याणां सहस्रेण कश्चिद्यतति सिद्धये ।
verses.transliteration: manuṣyāṇāṁ sahasreṇa kaścid yatati siddhaye ||
verses.translation: manuṣyāṇām — of humans/men; sahasreṇa — among thousands; kaścit — some one; yatati — strives/endeavors; siddhaye — for attainment/perfection.
verses.context: Chapter 7 (Jñāna‑vijñāna) moves from metaphysical description of the Lord’s nature to the conditions for realizing that knowledge. Krishna observes that true seekers are rare: of thousands, only one may ardently strive for spiritual perfection. The verse frames the scarcity of wholehearted aspirants against the background of worldly distractions and the powerful conditioned tendencies that keep most people bound. It explains why the path of knowledge and devotion requires decisive commitment and why Krishna’s teaching is offered to the few who will persist.
verses.explanation: This verse normalizes struggle. Difficulty does not mean inadequacy; it means the path is demanding.
verses.detailed_explanation: This observation can ease feelings of isolation for modern seekers: spiritual progress or deep mastery is uncommon not because of failure but because it requires sustained, often countercultural effort. Psychologically, it highlights selection bias — many start but few persist. For contemporary practice, this encourages realistic expectations and commitment strategies (habit design, community support, incremental goals). Recognizing rarity reframes comparison into a call to steady, patient engagement rather than shame, promoting resilience and long‑term growth.

verses.sanskrit: दैवी ह्येषा गुणमयी मम माया दुरत्यया । मामेव ये प्रपद्यन्ते मायामेतां तरन्ति ते ॥
verses.transliteration: daivī hy eṣā guṇamayī mama māyā duratyayā | mām eva ye prapadyante māyām etāṁ taranti te ||
verses.translation: daivī — divine; hi — indeed; eṣā — this; guṇamayī — composed of the gunas (qualities/modes); mama — my; māyā — māyā/illusory power; duratyayā — difficult to cross/overcome; mām eva — Me alone; ye — those who; prapadyante — surrender/seek refuge; māyām etām — this māyā (illusion/energy); taranti — they cross over; te — they.
verses.context: Still in Chapter 7, Krishna distinguishes between the impersonal influence of the three guṇas (sattva, rajas, tamas) and His personal, divine aspect. He calls his māyā a divine power constituted by the guṇas and admits its strength and subtlety: it is hard to transcend. The verse establishes surrender (prapadya) to the personal Divine as the way to transcend conditioned nature. It sets up a theological point: while the guṇas bind most beings, devotion to Krishna provides a direct means to overcome that binding power.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically, this verse frames habitual modes (gunas) as a powerful, subtle conditioning—an internal ‘māyā’ that sustains automatic patterns. Surrender here means shifting identity and agency toward a stabilizing center, enabling a person to disengage from entrenched drives. In modern practice, this suggests combining humility and committed orientation (to values, community, or a guiding principle) with interventions that weaken automaticity (mindfulness, cognitive restructuring, environment design). The result is greater capacity to override entrenched habits and enact chosen, value-led behaviors.

verses.sanskrit: अनन्याश्चिन्तयन्तो मां ये जनाः पर्युपासते । तेषां नित्याभ्युक्तानां योगक्षेमं वहाम्यहम् ॥
verses.transliteration: ananyāś cintayanto māṁ ye janāḥ paryupāsate teṣāṁ nityābhyuktānāṁ yogakṣemaṁ vahāmyaham
verses.translation: ananyāḥ — (those) without other (exclusive); cintayantaḥ — thinking; mām — of Me; ye janāḥ — who persons; paryupāsate — worship/devote/serve attentively; teṣām — of them; nitya — always; abhyuktānām — being attached/devoted; yoga-kṣemaṁ — (yoga) spiritual discipline/union and kṣema (security, maintenance, welfare); vahāmi — I bear/carry/provide; aham — I (indeed). Literal: "Those persons who think of Me exclusively and worship Me — for them, ever-devoted, I bear/provide the yoga and the welfare (their spiritual attainment and maintenance)."
verses.context: This verse occurs in the Atma‑jnana and Bhakti teaching section of the Bhagavad Gita (Chapter 9, the Rāja‑Vidyā Rāja‑Guhya yoga). Krishna is addressing Arjuna after revealing His divine nature and the inner secret of devotion. Here He reassures those who practice single‑minded devotion (ananya‑bhakti) that He personally sustains both their spiritual progress (yoga) and their material needs (kṣema). The narrative setting is Krishna consoling and guiding Arjuna on how devotion integrates with duty, showing that surrender to the Divine does not negate practical care but secures it.
verses.explanation: Stability invites support. This verse encourages consistency rather than panic.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically, this verse comforts the anxious mind by promising reliable support for focused devotion. It reduces existential dread by linking sustained inner attention to an external assurance of care. Modern application: cultivate consistent, single‑pointed commitment (to values, practice, or relationships); that steadiness stabilizes cognition and behavior, enabling resilience. In therapy or self‑work, committing to small daily practices (mindfulness, compassionate action) mirrors 'ananya bhakti' and accrues both inner development (yoga) and practical well‑being (kṣema). This reframes devotion as active, reliable psychological infrastructure.

verses.sanskrit: पत्रं पुष्पं फलं तोयं यो मे भक्त्या प्रयच्छति । तदहम्भक्त्युपहृतं अश्नामि प्रयतात्मनः ॥
verses.transliteration: patraṁ puṣpaṁ phalaṁ toyaṁ yo me bhaktyā prayacchati tad aham bhakty-upahṛtaṁ aśnāmi prayatātmanah
verses.translation: patram — a leaf; puṣpam — a flower; phalam — a fruit; toyam — water; yaḥ — who; me — to Me; bhaktyā — with devotion/devotional attitude; prayacchati — offers/presents; tad — that; aham — I; bhakty-upahṛtam — taken/received with devotion (i.e., offered with devotion); aśnāmi — I accept/consume; prayatātmanah — O self‑controlled one / O earnest‑spirited one. Literal: "A leaf, a flower, a fruit, water — whoever offers these to Me with devotion, that (offering) I, taken by devotion, accept, O earnest‑spirited one."
verses.context: In the same chapter of the Gita where Krishna elaborates the nature of devotion and divine grace, this verse addresses the propriety of offerings. Krishna tells Arjuna that the external value of a gift is secondary to the inner attitude with which it is given. In the narrative Krishna is expanding the meaning of worship: ritual materials (leaf, flower, fruit, water) are acceptable if offered with bhakti (devotion). Philosophically, this elevates intention over external form and aligns ritual action with inner ethics, making devotion accessible to all.
verses.explanation: Meaning lies in sincerity, not scale.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse underscores that small, sincere acts carry real worth — a potent remedy for perfectionism and performance anxiety. Psychologically, it affirms that intention and focused presence confer value upon actions, reducing the pressure to produce grand gestures. In modern life, offering time, attention, or modest help with genuine care functions like the leaf or flower: it repairs relationships and builds meaning. For personal practice, prioritize mindful, heartfelt offerings (a listening ear, consistent kindness) over symbolic extravagance; the psyche responds to perceived sincerity, increasing trust and wellbeing.

verses.sanskrit: यत्त्करोषि यदश्नासि यज्जुहोषि ददासि यत् । यत्परित्यज्य तत्तेऽपि कुरु मदीयर्पणम् ॥
verses.transliteration: yat karoṣi yad aśnāsi yaj juhosi dadāsi yat yat parityajya tat te 'pi kuru madīy arpaṇam
verses.translation: yat — whatever; karoṣi — you do (perform); yad — whatever; aśnāsi — you eat; yat — whatever; juhosi — you offer (in sacrifice); dadāsi — you give; yat yat — whatever (and whatever) you, parityajya — having relinquished/renounced; tat te 'pi — that even; kuru — do; madīy — to Me; arpaṇam — as an offering/dedication. Literal: "Whatever you do, whatever you eat, whatever you offer in sacrifice or give away, and whatever you renounce — even that, do as an offering to Me."
verses.context: This verse follows Krishna’s teaching on integrating worldly action with devotion. In the narrative Krishna instructs Arjuna on karma and bhakti: daily activities, nourishment, gifts, and even renunciations should be performed as an offering to the Divine. Philosophically, it synthesizes karma‑yoga and bhakti: by dedicating all actions to God, one removes personal attachment to outcomes and transforms work into worship. Thus ordinary life becomes a path of liberation when performed with right orientation and surrender.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically, dedicating actions beyond self‑interest reduces burnout by shifting motivation from egoic gain to value‑driven purpose. This externalization can diminish shame and performance anxiety while increasing intrinsic motivation and meaning. In modern application, reframe tasks (work, caregiving, chores) as contributions to a larger aim or as expressions of values; this reorientation sustains engagement and resilience. Clinically, such perspective shifts help clients convert drudgery into service, improving mood and persistence without denying realistic boundaries or self‑care.

verses.sanskrit: समानोऽहं सर्वभूतानां न मे द्वेष्योऽस्ति न मित्रः । येभ्यः कामः शुभाशुभेभ्यश्च ते तत्ते त्यक्त्वा मार्ग मम ॥
verses.transliteration: samaḥ o 'ham sarva-bhūtānāṁ na me dveṣyo 'sti na mitraḥ ye bhyaḥ kāmaḥ śubha-aśubhebhyaś ca te tat te tyaktvā mārga mama
verses.translation: samaḥ — equal/unbiased; aham — I am; sarva-bhūtānām — toward all beings; na — not; me — my; dveṣyaḥ — object of hatred; asti — is/there is; na — not; mitraḥ — (an) intimate friend/favored one; ye — those; bhyaḥ — from whom; kāmaḥ — desire/attachment; śubha-aśubhebhyaḥ — (toward) auspicious and inauspicious things; ca — and; te — they; tat te — those (things); tyaktvā — having renounced; mārga — path/way; mama — mine. Literal: "I am equal to all beings; for Me there is neither hate nor friend; from whom desires (arise) toward good and bad things — having renounced those, follow My path."
verses.context: In this portion of Chapter 9 Krishna clarifies the impartiality of the divine toward beings. Narratively, Krishna speaks to Arjuna about His transcendence of partiality and personal preference. Philosophically, the verse emphasizes non‑discrimination: God’s relation to creatures is not based on favoritism, and those who transcend attachments to pleasant and unpleasant results and abandon dualistic desires align themselves with the divine path. It calls for equanimity and detachment as prerequisites for realizing God’s universal outlook.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse addresses cognitive bias and emotional reactivity by portraying an attitude of radical equanimity. Psychologically, cultivating impartiality reduces resentment and the cycle of favoritism that distorts relationships. Modern application: practice noticing preferences and the aversion/attraction dynamic, then intentionally choosing actions that transcend these impulses (e.g., fair decision‑making, compassionate leadership). For personal wellbeing, letting go of binary judgments about events decreases rumination and increases mental flexibility, supporting ethical behavior and clearer perspective in conflict and moral choice.

verses.sanskrit:
दृष्ट्वेदं मानुषं रूपं रघुनन्दन कृपाश्रियं मया ।
दुरात्मनं तमग्निमिव सन्तापं हृत्स्थं मयोदितम्॥
verses.transliteration:
dṛṣṭvedam mānuṣaṁ rūpaṁ raghunandana kṛpāśriyaṁ mayā |
durātmanam tam agnim iva santāpaṁ hṛt-sthaṁ mayoditam ||
verses.translation: Seeing this human form, O delight of the Raghus, imbued with mercy by me — the wicked one (or one of evil mind) like fire, the suffering placed in the heart by me.
verses.context: After beholding Krishna's universal (viśvarūpa) vision, Arjuna feels overwhelmed by the cosmic form and asks Krishna to resume his familiar human, personal form. This verse is Arjuna's expression upon seeing Krishna change back (or seeking that change): it situates the narrative at the climax of the theophany in chapter 11, where the personal relationship between devotee and Lord is reasserted after the overwhelming, terrifying disclosure of divinity. Philosophically it contrasts the terrifying, all-consuming absolute with the relatable personal guide who inspires devotion and steadies the mind.
verses.explanation: Familiarity restores balance after shock. Stability matters as much as insight.
verses.detailed_explanation: Arjuna’s plea to see Krishna’s human form reflects a psychological need for an anchoring relationship after traumatic awe. The mind can be destabilized by overwhelming experiences; a known face provides containment, empathy, and relational safety. Modern application: in therapy or leadership, extraordinary insight must be coupled with compassionate presence. When people face vast, incomprehensible change, returning to a trusted human connection—clear communication, steady support—helps integrate insights into daily life and reduces existential panic.

verses.sanskrit:
ये तु अक्षरं अनिर्देश्यमव्यक्तं च ये च सर्वत्रागमचित्त्यशब्दरूपं च ते ।
तेषामहं समाबھ्य रक्षामि॥
verses.transliteration:
ye tu akṣaram anirdeśyam avyaktam ca ye ca sarvatrāgama-cintya-śabda-rūpam ca te |
teṣām ahaṁ samābhya rakṣāmi ||
verses.translation: But those who contemplate the imperishable, the indefinable, the unmanifest, and those who everywhere come and whose form is unthinkable and of sound (word) — them I protect uniformly.
verses.context: In the Bhakti-yoga section (chapter 12), Krishna addresses Arjuna's question about whether it is better to worship the formless (akṣara/avyakta) or the personal Lord. This verse distinguishes types of devotees: those who fix themselves on the imperishable, the indefinable unmanifest reality (the nirguṇa, avyakta Brahman) and those inclined to a subtle, pervasive conception. Krishna here reassures that he preserves and supports sincere seekers regardless of whether their devotion targets the personal or impersonal aspect of the Divine, bridging the philosophical divide between jñāna and bhakti.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse highlights psychological diversity in spiritual orientation: some people gravitate toward abstract, conceptual truth while others seek a personal relationship. Both orientations arise from temperament and cognitive style. Modern application: in counseling or workplace coaching, tailor approaches—some clients respond to principles and systems (the 'formless'), others to relational mentorship (the 'personal'). Recognize and protect sincere seekers regardless of method; institutional flexibility and personalized guidance foster resilience and sustained growth.

verses.sanskrit:
सन्नियाम्येन्द्रियग्रामं सर्वभूताशयस्थितम् ।
मनः सर्वस्थं तत्कालभक्त्या समर्पयेत् ॥
verses.transliteration:
sanniyamy endriya-grāmaṁ sarva-bhūta-āśaya-sthitam |
manah sarva-sthaṁ tat-kāla-bhaktyā samarpayet ||
verses.translation: Having restrained the hosts of the senses, established in the abodes of all beings, the mind dwelling everywhere — that (mind) at the appropriate time one should surrender with devotion.
verses.context: Continuing Arjuna’s question in chapter 12, Krishna outlines the discipline required for those who concentrate on the unmanifest Brahman. This verse emphasizes control of the senses (indriya-samvara) and a mind that is steady yet impartial, residing in the experience of all beings. It advises that such a disciplined, universally situated mind should be dedicated (surrendered) in devotion. Philosophically it links ethical self-regulation with universal compassion and the devotional act of offering the purified mind to the divine.
verses.detailed_explanation: This teaching underlines how self-regulation cultivates an equanimous, outward-facing mind rather than repression. Psychologically, restraining reactive impulses allows empathy and perspective-taking—placing the mind 'in the abode of all beings.' Modern application includes mindfulness practices that reduce impulsive reactivity, enabling ethical choices and compassionate action. Surrender here is deliberate: offering a disciplined, open attention to values or purpose (a loved one, community, or vocation) channels willpower into sustainable prosocial behavior rather than brittle, self-directed suppression.

verses.sanskrit:
क्लेशकैरधिकतरास्तेषामव्यक्तासक्तचेतसाम् ।
अव्यक्ता य एव सर्वान्ता तेऽत्यन्तं तिष्ठति हृषीकेश ॥
verses.transliteration:
kleśakaiḥ adhikataraḥ teṣām avyakta-āsakta-cetasām |
avyaktā ya eva sarvāntā te'tyantaṁ tiṣṭhati hṛṣīkeśa ||
verses.translation: For hard is the suffering to a greater degree for those whose minds are attached to the unmanifest; the unmanifest alone is the end for them — it (alone) very much endures, O Hṛṣīkeśa.
verses.context: Krishna explains the relative difficulty of the yoga of meditating on the unmanifest (avyakta). Here he acknowledges that for many aspirants the formless path is beset with greater obstacles (kleśa), because the unmanifest object offers less sensory and emotional support for devotion. The verse contrasts the enduring nature of the unmanifest Absolute with the psychological difficulty of keeping an abstract ideal as the sole object of attachment, thereby recommending appropriate practice according to temperament.
verses.explanation: Wisdom must meet people where they are. Unrealistic ideals often create guilt rather than growth.
verses.detailed_explanation: Krishna acknowledges a common psychological truth: abstract ideals are harder to hold steadily than relatable, personal anchors. Attachment to an impersonal Absolute can increase confusion and inner struggle when the mind seeks relational cues. Practically, this suggests progressive scaffolding—start with concrete practices, symbols, or relationships and gradually refine toward more abstract insight. In therapy or learning, begin with embodied, relational interventions before moving to abstract conceptualization, ensuring the person remains supported and not overwhelmed.

verses.sanskrit: ये तु सर्वाणि कर्माणि मयि संन्यस्य मत्पराः भावसम्प्रेक्ष्याः यान्ति ब्रह्मसिद्धिं परमम्॥
verses.transliteration: Ye tu sarvāṇi karmāṇi mayi saṃnyasya mat-parāḥ bhāva-samprekṣyāḥ yānti brahma-siddhiṃ paramam
verses.translation: But those (ye tu) all (sarvāṇi) actions (karmāṇi) in Me (mayi) renouncing (saṃnyasya), devoted-to-Me (mat-parāḥ), with contemplative regard/seeing with feeling (bhāva-samprekṣyāḥ), go (yānti) to (to attain) the supreme (paramam) realization/attainment of Brahman (brahma-siddhiṃ).
verses.context: In the middle of his exposition on bhakti-yoga, Krishna contrasts two ways: devotion directed to the personal Lord and the path of formless meditation. Here he explains that those who surrender their actions to Krishna and keep their orientation fixed on Him — while mentally contemplating His presence — attain the highest spiritual completion. This verse follows the earlier distinctions about worshiping the unmanifest and emphasizes that wholehearted surrender of action and steady orientation toward the Lord lead to Brahman-realization within the narrative of Arjuna's moral and spiritual dilemma.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically, this verse invites reappraisal of daily tasks: when work is surrendered to a larger purpose and experienced as offering rather than mere duty, it reduces inner conflict and rumination. Modern application: reframe chores and professional duties as contributions to a relationship or higher aim, observe feelings during action (contemplation), and let identification shift from ego outcomes to steadier motivation. This reduces anxiety and fosters resilience, because purpose reorients attention from transient results to sustained meaning.

verses.sanskrit: अद्वेष्टा सर्वभूतानां मैत्रः करुण एव च॥
verses.transliteration: Adveṣṭā sarva-bhūtānāṃ maitraḥ karuṇa eva ca
verses.translation: No-hater (adveṣṭā) of all beings (sarva-bhūtānām), friendly (maitraḥ), compassionate indeed (karuṇa eva ca).
verses.context: Krishna is describing the inner qualities of an ideal devotee. After discussing how orientation toward the divine can be practiced through action and mental focus, he lists ethical and psychological virtues that mark one who is established in devotion: absence of hostility, active friendliness, and compassion toward all creatures. This is set within the conversational context where Arjuna seeks practical markers of spiritual maturity in the midst of moral crisis.
verses.explanation: Hatred binds more tightly than attachment. Freedom begins with goodwill.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically the verse points to an antipathetic-free baseline: reducing automatic antagonism frees cognitive resources and softens reactivity. Practically, cultivating friendliness and compassion—through perspective-taking, small acts of kindness, and mindful pauses—interrupts hostile scripts and diminishes rumination. In modern life this lowers stress, improves relationships, and supports prosocial behavior at work and home. The practice is not naive passivity but an intentional rewiring of habitual defensive responses into empathic engagement.

verses.sanskrit: निर्ममो निरहङ्कारः समदुःखसुखः क्षमी॥
verses.transliteration: Nirmamo nirahaṅkāraḥ sama-duḥkha-sukhaḥ kṣamī
verses.translation: Without-attachment (nirmamaḥ), without-egoism (nirahaṅkāraḥ), equal-in-suffering-and-happiness (sama-duḥkha-sukhaḥ), forgiving (kṣamī).
verses.context: Continuing the character sketch of the devotee, Krishna names qualities that free one from inner turbulence: lack of possessiveness, absence of egoic pride, evenness of mind amid pleasure and pain, and the power to forgive. These traits are presented as practical psychological dispositions cultivated by steady devotion and surrender, showing how inner equanimity supports sustained spiritual practice amid the battlefield imagery of the Gita.
verses.explanation: Contentment is not stagnation; it is emotional stability.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse highlights psychological equanimity: loosening attachment and ego reduces threat sensitivity and emotional volatility. Being able to experience pleasure and pain without being destabilized supports better decision-making and lowers chronic stress. Modern techniques—cognitive defusion, acceptance, and perspective-taking—mirror Krishna’s advice: practice non-possession, observe egoic narratives, and cultivate forgiveness to restore relational harmony and resilience in work and personal life.

verses.sanskrit: यस्मान्नोद्विजते लोको लोकान्नोद्विजते च यः । हर्षामर्षभयो-द्वेगैर् मुक्तो यः स च मे प्रियः ॥
verses.transliteration: Yasmān nodvijate loko lokān nodvijate ca yaḥ | harṣāmarṣabhayo-dvegair mukto yaḥ sa ca me priyaḥ ||
verses.translation: From whom the world is not agitated (yasmān nodvijate loka), who does not agitate the world (lokān nodvijate ca yaḥ); by joy, anger, envy, fear and agitation (harṣa-amarṣa-bhaya-dvegaiḥ) freed (muktaḥ) is he; such a one (yaḥ) is dear to Me (sa ca me priyaḥ).
verses.context: Krishna emphasizes relational steadiness as hallmark of the beloved devotee. In the sequence describing virtues, he singles out one who neither disturbs others nor is disturbed by them, and who is liberated from extremes of emotion; such stability makes one especially dear to the Lord. The instruction comes as practical counsel for Arjuna to cultivate inner non-reactivity during his duties on the battlefield and in life.
verses.explanation: Emotional maturity shows in calm presence, not withdrawal.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse pinpoints non-reactivity: the ideal is reciprocal calm—one who neither provokes nor is provoked. Psychologically it means reducing reactivity cycles that escalate conflicts. Modern application includes practicing impulse control, emotional labeling, and exposure to discomfort so typical triggers lose power. Such steadiness improves interpersonal trust and decision clarity. Being 'dear' in Krishna’s terms corresponds to being reliable, compassionate, and emotionally regulated—qualities prized in leadership, parenting, and partnerships.

verses.sanskrit: अनपेक्षः शुचिर्दक्ष उदासीनो गुणैः यः पश्यति । न स बन्धुं न मित्रं न शत्रुं ॥
verses.transliteration: Anapekṣaḥ śucir dakṣa udāsīnaḥ guṇaiḥ yaḥ paśyati | na sa bandhuṁ na mitraṁ na śatruṁ ||
verses.translation: Unattached, pure, dexterous, and indifferent, who sees by the gunas; not a relative, not a friend, not an enemy.
verses.context: Qualities of devotion in action. In Chapter 12 Arjuna asks about the nature of a devoted person. Krishna describes a bhakta's mental steadiness and equanimity. This verse points to someone whose conduct is not governed by expectant liking or disliking and whose perception sees actions and people through the play of the three guṇas (sattva, rajas, tamas). Such a person transcends ordinary personal categories (kin/friend/enemy) because attachment and expectation no longer determine relations.
verses.explanation: Freedom grows when dependence on approval fades.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically, this verse points to mature agency: action without expectation quiets anxiety about outcomes and social appraisal. Purity (śuci) and skill (dakṣa) indicate competent, ethical competence; udāsīnatā (detachment) prevents reactive identity-formation. Modern application: cultivate professional competence and ethical clarity while reducing outcome-fixation — practice doing your role fully without tying self-worth to praise, which reduces stress, improves relationships, and fosters steady performance.

verses.sanskrit: यो न हृष्यति न द्वेष्टि न शोचति न काङ्क्षति । शुभाशुभपरित्यागी भक्तिमान्यः स मे प्रियः ॥
verses.transliteration: Yo na hṛṣyati na dveṣṭi na śocati na kāṅkṣati | śubhāśubha parityāgī bhakti-mānyaḥ sa me priyaḥ ||
verses.translation: One who neither rejoices nor hates nor grieves nor desires; renouncing both good and bad, a devotee is dear to me.
verses.context: Balanced emotional life. Here Krishna explains that the truly devoted person is emotionally steady: free from reactive joy and hatred, grief and craving. The emphasis is on relinquishing attachment to both what is conventionally 'good' and 'bad' (shubha-ashubha) and on prioritising devotion (bhakti). This explains why such a person is beloved to the Divine: devotion anchored in equanimity is unshakeable.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically, the verse outlines emotional regulation: absence of reactive elation, hatred, sorrow, and craving indicates resilience. Letting go of binary good/bad attachments reduces rumination and mood volatility. For modern life, practice noticing impulses to celebrate or reject, then return to steady intention (e.g., service, values). Prioritizing devotion or meaningful purpose rather than outcomes helps reduce anxiety, stabilize relationships, and sustain motivation across setbacks.

verses.sanskrit: समानः शत्रौ च मित्रे च तथा मानापमानयोः । शीतोष्णसुखदुःखेषु समः सङ्गविवर्जितः ॥
verses.transliteration: Samānaḥ śatrau ca mitre ca tathā mānāpamānayoḥ | śītoṣṇa-sukha-duḥkheṣu samaḥ saṅga-vivarjitaḥ ||
verses.translation: Being equal toward friend and foe, and toward honor and dishonor; in cold and heat, in pleasure and pain; he is equal, free from attachment.
verses.context: Krishna defines emotional impartiality. This verse expands on equanimity by giving concrete pairs — friend/enemy, honour/dishonour, heat/cold, pleasure/pain — showing a bhakta's consistent inner balance. In the narrative, Krishna is instructing Arjuna on how devotion manifests as steady conduct regardless of external fluctuations. The practical teaching is that true devotion (and wise action) maintains impartiality amid life's opposites.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse maps to emotional intelligence: equalizing responses to praise/blame, comfort/discomfort reduces reactivity and impulsive behavior. Psychologically it cultivates tolerance, reduces rumination, and strengthens decision-making under pressure. Modern application: train attention (mindfulness) to notice hedonic swings and deliberately sustain impartial action — whether in leadership, caregiving, or daily stress — leading to clearer judgments and healthier relationships.

verses.sanskrit: तुल्यनिन्दास्तुतिर्मौन्यः समः सर्वेषु भूमिषु । नात्यत्ययेन धर्मः स्वभावे स्थितो न लिप्यते ॥
verses.transliteration: Tulya-nindā-stutir maunyoḥ samaḥ sarveṣu bhūmiṣu | nātyatyayena dharmaḥ svabhāve sthito na lipyate ||
verses.translation: Blame and praise and silence are equal in all the worlds; not by excess is dharma established in its own nature, nor is it stained.
verses.context: Krishna describes inner independence. This verse continues the catalogue of steadiness: being equal in praise and blame, inclined to measured speech, consistent in conduct across contexts, and having one's dharma rooted in nature rather than fickle shifts. In the narrative, it reassures Arjuna that such constancy is the hallmark of a devotee whose actions are not contaminated by social swings or emotional turbulence.
verses.explanation: External validation loses power when self-trust grows.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically, the verse advocates internalized values over external oscillations: when moral conduct becomes habitual and identity-rooted, praise and blame have less sway. Silence here signals reflective restraint rather than impulsive defense. Modern application: build integrity through small consistent choices (habit formation), practice measured speech, and let core principles guide actions so that social feedback does not derail ethical behavior or self-worth.

verses.sanskrit: महाभूतानि अहङ्कारो बुद्धिरव्यक्तमेव च
verses.transliteration: mahā-bhūtāni ahaṅkāro buddhir avyaktam eva ca
verses.translation: mahā‑bhūtāni — the great/elements; ahaṅkāraḥ — ego / sense of "I"; buddhiḥ — intellect / discriminative reason; avyaktam — the unmanifest / the unmanifested; eva ca — and indeed.
verses.context: This verse occurs in the Kṣetra–Kṣetrajña section (chapter 13) of the Bhagavad‑Gītā. Arjuna has asked Krishna to distinguish the field (kṣetra — the body, senses, mind and material components) and the knower of the field (kṣetrajña). Krishna begins enumerating constituents of the field: the five gross elements and related interior principles (ego, intellect) and the unmanifest (avyakta) substrate. Narratively this is Krishna teaching in the Kurukṣetra battlefield, philosophically situating ordinary identity within a composite of material and subtle factors rather than as the true, unmixed Self.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically this verse dismantles a unitary, rigid self‑image by listing the building blocks of our experienced identity: elemental sensations, egoic I‑sense, intellect and the unmanifest processes. Recognizing oneself as a composite reduces overidentification with any single aspect (thoughts, roles, sensations). In modern therapy and mindfulness practices this allows cognitive distancing and flexibility: instead of ‘‘I am my anger,’’ one can observe anger as an arising element within the field. That shift alleviates anxiety, enhances self‑regulation and opens space for wiser choice and compassionate action.
verses.explanation: Seeing components loosens fixation on self-image.

verses.sanskrit: अमानित्वं अदम्भित्वं अहिंसा क्षान्तिरार्जवम्
verses.transliteration: amānitvam adambhitvam ahiṃsā kṣāntir ārjavam
verses.translation: amānitvam — humility / absence of conceit; adambhitvam — lack of hypocrisy / straightforwardness (absence of deceit); ahiṃsā — non‑violence / harmlessness; kṣāntiḥ — forbearance / patience; ārjavam — sincerity / straightforwardness / simplicity.
verses.context: Following the inventory of material and subtle components of the field, Krishna lists ethical and temperamental qualities that clarify cognition and purify the field. In the dialogue on knowledge and the knower, these virtues are presented as supports for correct understanding. Within the Kurukṣetra setting Krishna addresses Arjuna’s confusion, moving from metaphysical description to practical dispositions—humility, absence of deceit, non‑injury, patience and simple honesty—that foster true perception and steady the intellect.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse pinpoints interpersonal and intrapersonal virtues that cultivate clear perception and reduce defensive reactivity. Humility dissolves grandiose self‑stories; non‑deceit and sincerity remove the inner split between presented self and felt self; non‑violence and patience reduce impulsive harm. Applied today, these traits support psychological safety in relationships and effective leadership: they lower threat responses, invite honest feedback, and enable emotion regulation. Practicing them strengthens neural pathways for empathy and reduces rumination, promoting resilient, skillful action under stress.

verses.sanskrit: ज्ञानं विज्ञानं आत्मविनिग्रहः
verses.transliteration: jñānaṃ vijñānaṃ ātma‑vinigrahaḥ
verses.translation: jñānam — general knowledge; vijñānam — discriminative or realized knowledge (deep/reflective knowing); ātma‑vinigrahaḥ — restraint/conquest of the self (self‑control, mastery of the faculties).
verses.context: Continuing the list of qualities that refine the field and enable true knowing, Krishna here highlights cognitive virtues: ordinary knowledge and its deeper counterpart (vijñāna, often rendered as discriminative, experiential or realized understanding), together with self‑restraint. In the broader philosophical arc Krishna is showing how cultivation of knowledge and internal discipline prepares one to discern the knower (kṣetrajña) from the changing contents (kṣetra). For Arjuna, these are practical requisites for seeing clearly amid the moral complexity of battle.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse emphasizes that both information (jñāna) and transformative insight (vijñāna), supported by disciplined regulation of impulses (ātma‑vinigraha), are necessary for psychological maturity. In contemporary terms: factual learning must be partnered with reflective integration and executive control. Developing attention, impulse control and metacognition enables one to apply insight under pressure (e.g., in relationships or decision‑making). Therapies that combine skill training (self‑regulation) with cognitive reframing and experiential insight mirror this triangular prescription for durable change.

verses.sanskrit: मयी चान्ययोगेन भावानव्ययमनुपश्यति
verses.transliteration: mayi cānanya‑yogena bhāvam avyayam anu paśyati
verses.translation: mayi — in Me; ca — and; ananya‑yogena — by non‑other (exclusive) devotion/yoga; bhāvam — the state/being (that which is); avyayam — imperishable / not subject to decay; anu paśyati — he sees/observes (he perceives). (Literal sense: By exclusive yoga/devotion he perceives the imperishable state in Me.)
verses.context: This verse appears where Krishna describes the realization of the immutable reality (avyaya) through focused, exclusive orientation (ananya‑yoga) toward the divine ground. Within the Kṣetra–Kṣetrajña teaching the line points to the experiential outcome of cultivating the listed virtues and knowledge: one who rests in undistracted turning toward the Self (here spoken of in relation to Krishna) perceives the imperishable substratum. Narratively Krishna assures Arjuna that sustained, exclusive practice reveals the eternal beneath transient phenomena.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically this verse centers on the power of sustained, singular attention (ananya‑yoga) to reveal a stable sense of selfhood beyond fleeting moods and roles. Modern application: focused contemplative practice or committed therapeutic work—when consistently applied—uncovers resilient core wellbeing (the ‘imperishable’). It counters fragmentation by building integrative awareness, reduces reactivity, and supports ethical clarity. For those struggling with churn, dedicating regular time to undistracted inward practice produces durable perceptual shifts: one begins to experience continuity beyond transient mental states.

verses.sanskrit:
पुरुषः प्रकृतिस्तो हि भूता धात्मा प्रकृत्यास्थितः ।
पुरुषः प्रकृतिस्तो हि भूता धात्मा प्रकृत्यास्थितः ।
verses.transliteration:
puruṣaḥ prakṛti-sto hi bhūtā dhātmā prakṛtyā sthitaḥ ।
puruṣaḥ prakṛti-sto hi bhūtā dhātmā prakṛtyā sthitaḥ ।
verses.translation: puruṣaḥ — the person/the self; prakṛti-staḥ — situated in (or dependent on) nature; hi — indeed; bhūta-dhātmā — the essence/base of the elements/beings; prakṛtyā sthitaḥ — fixed/placed in nature. Literal: "The person — indeed situated in nature, the essence of beings, placed in (and by) nature."
verses.context: In chapter 13 Krishna distinguishes kṣetra (the field) and kṣetrajña (the knower of the field). Here he characterizes the embodied self (puruṣa) as located in and conditioned by prakṛti (nature) while pointing to its relational position to the field of material existence. This verse helps Arjuna understand the dependent and situated aspect of the individual self within the cosmic interplay of nature and consciousness.
verses.detailed_explanation: Psychologically, this verse highlights how the sense of self is often experienced as lodged within conditioned patterns (prakṛti): habits, emotions, and identifications. Recognizing the self as "situated in nature" reduces absolute identification with transient feelings and roles. Practically, it invites modern readers to observe their conditioned responses without mistaking them for the whole self. This stance supports therapeutic detachment — noticing thoughts and impulses as products of conditioning enables choice, regulation, and a freer, less reactive life.

verses.sanskrit:
ध्यानेनात्मानं पश्यन्ति यावन्त्येति च सूक्ष्मतः ।
ध्यानेनात्मानं पश्यन्ति यावन्त्येति च सूक्ष्मतः ।
verses.transliteration:
dhyānena ātmānaṃ paśyanti yāvanty eti ca sūkṣmataḥ ।
dhyānena ātmānaṃ paśyanti yāvanty eti ca sūkṣmataḥ ।
verses.translation: dhyānena — by meditation; ātmānam — the self; paśyanti — (they) see; yāvanty — the extent/that which exists; eti — approaches / is perceived; ca — and; sūkṣmataḥ — with subtlety. Literal: "By meditation they perceive the self, perceiving with subtlety that which exists (and its extent)."
verses.context: Krishna here emphasizes direct experiential knowledge through dhyāna (meditative seeing). Following the analysis of field and knower, he points out the method by which wise persons realize the self: sustained meditative insight that discriminates subtle realities. This occurs within the teaching flow that moves from metaphysical distinctions into the practical means of realisation — perception, discrimination, and meditative clarity.
verses.detailed_explanation: This verse underscores focused reflection (dhyāna) as a means to see inner processes clearly. In contemporary terms it parallels mindfulness and introspective practices that reveal underlying mental patterns and subtle motivations. Psychologically, disciplined observation sharpens meta-awareness, enabling one to notice the mechanics of emotion and thought before reacting. Applied today, it supports emotional regulation, clearer values-based decisions, and a reduction in impulsive behaviour by cultivating a consistent, subtle witnessing of inner life.

verses.sanskrit:
समं सर्वेषु भूतेषु दक्षिणं चापि समं हि ।
समं सर्वेषु भूतेषु द्रष्टव्यम् समता स्मृतिः ।
verses.transliteration:
samaṃ sarveṣu bhūteṣu dakṣiṇaṃ ca api samaṃ hi ।
samaṃ sarveṣu bhūteṣu draṣṭavyam samatā smṛtiḥ ।
verses.translation: samaṃ — equal/equanimous; sarveṣu bhūteṣu — in all beings; dakṣiṇam ca api — and toward the right (or generous act) also; samaṃ hi — indeed equal; draṣṭavyam — should be seen; samatā — equality/even-mindedness; smṛtiḥ — memory/awareness. Literal: "Equanimity toward all beings — and evenness in right action — should be seen; equality is to be remembered."
verses.context: Placed amid qualities of the knower and wise conduct, this verse stresses evenness of vision and action toward all living beings. Krishna is instructing Arjuna in how the realised person relates ethically and psychologically: maintaining impartiality, remembering equality in perception and conduct, which underpins non-violence and stable moral behavior in the larger teaching of duty and knowledge.
verses.detailed_explanation: This instruction cultivates an inner posture of impartial regard. Psychologically, even-mindedness reduces bias, projection, and reactive favoritism that distort relationships and decisions. Practically, it encourages fair treatment, steady generosity, and consistent ethical choices regardless of personal likes or dislikes. For modern application, practicing cognitive reappraisal and perspective-taking fosters this samatā, improving leadership, conflict resolution, and reducing emotional burnout by preventing over-identification with particular outcomes or persons.

verses.sanskrit:
समं पश्यन्न् हि सर्वत्र नैनं विभेदयति यः ।
समं पश्यन्न् हि सर्वत्र नैनं विभेदयति यः ।
verses.transliteration:
samaṃ paśyann hi sarvatra nainaṃ vibhedayati yaḥ ।
samaṃ paśyann hi sarvatra nainaṃ vibhedayati yaḥ ।
verses.translation: samaṃ — equally / with even vision; paśyann — seeing; hi — indeed; sarvatra — everywhere; na — not; enam — it (the self/duality) ; vibhedayati — divides/separates; yaḥ — he who. Literal: "He who sees equally everywhere indeed does not separate/divide (things)."
verses.context: Following the emphasis on samatā, this verse highlights the practical result: one who maintains equal vision does not create divisions or distinctions that lead to conflict and attachment. In the flow of chapter 13, Krishna is tying inner equanimity to ethical consequences: impartial perception dissolves the grounds for discrimination, conflict, and egoistic clinging, supporting the broader aim of knowledge-driven action.
verses.detailed_explanation: This counsel speaks to reducing dualistic reactions that fragment relationships and self-concept. Psychologically it invites noticing when categorizing or ranking others fuels resentment and separateness. Modern application includes practicing impartial observation, reducing us-vs-them thinking, and fostering inclusion.
